With presidential campaign drowning boredom, commentators desperately searching news, preferably new victim, brighten days. And along came Susan Rice. A couple Sundays ago, U.N. ambassador made mistake appearing talk shows insist attack U.S. consulate Benghazi, Libya, "spontaneous" rather terrorist plot. You would thought said pope Mormon. A25 HEADLINE: It's Rice BYLINE: Richard Cohen BODY: In 1953, Army officer name Irving Peress promoted captain major. Peress leftist, possibly communist, word advancement rank reached Sen. Joseph McCarthy Washington. He asserted promotion proved Army "soft communism," launched investigation transfixed nation. Peress, way, mere dentist. He Susan Rice day. Rice, course, much substantial figure. She U.N. ambassador, friend Barack Obama's member Cabinet. Still, attack disproportionate accused done - it, exactly? - Peress case, conclude something work. At first, I thought witnessing another example Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) Rumpelstiltskin number - throwing fit stomping feet. It McCain first leveled solemn charge Rice lied Sunday TV shows attack U.S. consulate Benghazi, Libya. She characterized spontaneous riot was, fact, planned attack local al-Qaeda affiliate. But Rice hewing early line established intelligence community. If CIA others wrong - deceptive - so, inevitably, she. Just surely day follows night, McCain's broadside echoed Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.). It soon taken 97 Republicans House found Rice unqualified become secretary state - post nominated. "Ambassador Rice widely viewed willfully incompetently misled American public," bellowed. I think Rice would make dandy secretary state. She's close president, matters great deal. But also seen overly political that, much version Benghazi, troubles others. Oddly enough, Sen. John Kerry (D-Mass.), former presidential candidate another potential secretary state, seen much statesmen. He indeed independent foreign-policy thinker has, days old, restored prestige importance Foreign Relations Committee, chairman. But awful truth hardly matters Obama chooses. Foreign policy run White House State Department. Benghazi, population one million country 6.5 million, Libya's second largest city and1/1 e'as epicenter revolution government Muammar Qaddafi 2011. On November 22, Benghazi police chief Farej Darssi assassinated. In October police colonel barely avoided death— car wired explode, A Libyan intelligence officer killed September. A general assassinated August. Some figures worked Qaddafi defected revolution. Qaddafi's security forces responsible 1996 massacre hardline fundamentalists Abu Salim prison, making others disappear, Likely shadowy cells attacked US consulate behind attacks Benghazi police army officers. There may break case. Last Saturday, Benghazi security forces loyal elected government Tripoli, captured man suspected involved groups behind violence. And, appears willing spill beans. So let's call Libyan Deep Throat. Deep Throat knowledgeable conspiracies facing city dangerous hatching latter immediately attempted spring jail. On Sunday morning, militants attacked police facility next holding cell man detained. A policeman station died hail bullets attackers, called back-up. The police car sped scene ambushed three policemen killed. Still, police stood ground fought assault, kept valuable suspect custody, valuable testimony. Then explosives set al-Uruba police station, also took sniper fire, neither resulted casualties. I've followed case Torture homefront cries justice Comments <http://www.suntimes.com/news/marin/1734591,CST-EDT-caro126.article> August 26, 2009 BY CAROL MARIN <mailto:cmarin@suntimes.com> Sun-Times Columnist The feds can't -- yet -- deport Michigan restaurateur Ibrahim Parlak native Turkey. But frighteningly closer. And irony screams out. Carol Mann On Monday, day Eric Holder, President Obama's attorney general, announced would appoint special counsel investigate whether torture used CIA extract confessions foreign suspects, U.S. appeals court behest U.S. government ruled didn't problem sending Parlak back country tortured -- imprisoned 17 months, shocked electrodes, hung arms sexually violated. A Turkish Kurd, Parlak granted political asylum 1992. It government got cozier Turkey, re-classified Kurdish separatist movement "terrorist" attacks Sept. 11. With 9/11, Ibrahim Parlak's horror began anew. Suddenly looked different newly created Department Homeland Security Justice Department's Immigration courts. Instead seeing hard-working, tax-paying Chamber Commerce member ran Cafe Gulistan, small Middle Eastern restaurant resort town Harbert, Mich., tlie feds saw international menace. In 2004, FBI grabbed Parlak locked up. If hadn't volunteer team lawyers, including Reagan-appointed former U.S. attorney, former FBI anti- terrorism legal adviser bipartisan intervention Michigan's Sen. Carl Levin, liberal Democrat, Rep. Fred Upton, conservative Republican, Parlak would still jail. Thanks them, 47-year-old father 12-year-old girl temporarily free. But barely. The newest outrage 2-1 decision issued Cincinnati's 6th Circuit Court Appeals day Holder launched torture inquiry. B5 The majority opinion issued two Bush appointees put bench 9/11. Judge Julia Smith Gibbons Judge Jeffrey Sutton upheld Justice Department's Immigration courts ruling Parlak failed disclose relationship now-labeled terrorist organization even though never proven member. Let's remember something immigration courts. They independent. They work whoever attorney general. And past rulings Parlak came two now-controversial Bush appointees, John Ashcroft Alberto Gonzales. The fairness immigration rulings ripped none Judge Richard Posner 7th Circuit Court Appeals, one nation's brilliant judges. By September 2005, Posner noted "a staggering 40 percent 136 petitions" reversed due to, according one ruling, willingness ignore "the basic facts." Echoing Posner dissenting judge Parlak appeal. Judge Boyce F. Martin, Carter appointee, writes clarity conviction, arguing government's "awesome power used railroad man country." Like surgeon, Martin dissects Justice Department's immigration courts majority opinion colleagues, ends saying, "I remain hopeful, nevertheless, case sad remnant era paranoid, overzealous, error-riddled misguided anti-terrorism immigration enforcement gone wayside. It shame that, even hope proves true, late Ibrahim Parlak." Parlak's legal team appeal. Meanwhile, Holder, like Ashcroft Gonzales him, new boss immigration courts. As investigates questions U.S. torture abroad, here's hoping Holder examines ongoing domestic legal torture Ibrahim Parlak.

April 11, 2009 12pm Word count: 2,392 (19 min) Rooney (x7-7203, 202-431-6498) SECRETARY OF STATE HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON REMARKS TO THE HAITI DONORS CONFERENCE Washington, D.C. Tuesday, April 14, 2009 For us, Haiti neighbor. For others, place historic cultural ties. For us, test collective commitment resolve. Some may ask small nation middle Caribbean Sea command attention today. Why countries Western Hemisphere, Europe, Middle East Asia offer assistance Haiti midst global economic downturn shaken us all. We're gathered conference happens Haiti resound far beyond Caribbean beyond Americas. The success failure one small nation economic, social political implications, 9 million citizens, region whose future shaped strength commitment achieve economic recovery, political progress wider opportunity people Portland Porto Alegre Port-au-Prince. The United States here, first foremost, right thing neighbor friend. Our ties Haiti reach back early years nations endured generations-through struggles independence; defeat slavery Haiti, inspired slaves abolitionists U.S. press fight freedom; recently, hundreds thousands Haitians emigrated United States strengthened contributions politics, business, science, sports culture-the benefits I experienced firsthand senator representing New York. We also committed creating hemisphere every nation-no matter present level wealth current political circumstances-is moving direction, toward greater peace, prosperity, freedom opportunity. With Haiti, chance global cooperation collaboration stand solidarity people seeking march forward. A nation small investments assistance countries beginning reap dividends economic growth, wider access health care, stronger governmental institutions, greater safety security-and higher quality life results material conditions people's lives improve. Today, Haiti poorest nation hemisphere, one region's biggest gaps haves have- nots. But 2006, Haiti highest economic growth since 1990s. It track reach completion point IMF's Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative next months, means significant debt relief way, free approximately $4 million month-money Haiti invest directly improving lives people building future self-sufficiency confidence. Haiti region's highest rate HIV/AIDS, highest rate maternal mortality, highest rate child mortality. But numbers HIV infections child maternal deaths coming down. Not long ago, Haiti endured three decades brutal dictatorship. But national presidential elections 2006 jump-started Haiti's democracy, President Preval Prime Minister Pierre Louis seeking maintain strong commitment democratic governance, take another step forward Sunday elections Senate. Like many nations, including United States, Haiti struggles crime, particularly global scourge drug trafficking. But reforms improve policing, strengthen justice system fight corruption underway, peacekeeping force led Brazil helped bring stability many Haitian communities. Haiti made strides help citizens many nations institutions represented today. And progress come government-to-government partnerships, also links among businesses, universities, NG0s, religious cultural groups, individuals-the full range resources relationships, heart smart power. That trajectory progress undermined combined winds hurricanes global economic recession. Haiti danger stalling. This conference gives us opportunity reignite path progress work team-with Haiti helm-to advance comprehensive, long-term strategy Haiti's growth, coordinating hemispheric international efforts, targeting clear goals, deploying diverse skills resources efficiently effectively. President Preval Prime Minister Pierre Louis identified help Haiti needs get back track. With priorities guide Haiti partner, make high-impact investments help lay foundation stronger democratic institutions, vibrant civil society, open market economy creates stability, attracts international investment, offers jobs wider economic opportunities Haiti region whole. Now time step investment Haiti-not situation dire, consequences inaction could lead significantly larger costs human financial terms road. With $100, pay year schooling one Haitian child immunize five. That's tiny fraction cost solving problems escalate time. The United States target support toward three areas Haitian government requested, aimed promoting conditions essential national regional progress. First, Haitian people need secure. They must able travel safely work school participate civic lives communities without fear violence. Second, country needs stronger infrastructure, particularly roads, circulatory system robust economy. Meanwhile, people Haiti ready work, jobs short supply. We accomplish two things putting people work building roads infrastructure throughout Haiti. And third, last year's hurricanes blew hole government's budget. Now Haiti facing huge deficit, make harder provide services short-term fund major projects long-term. Their debt obligations constrain ability lay groundwork future. On issues-security, jobs infrastructure, debt relief-the United States lending assistance seeking partner nations maximize collective impact. First, security. Effective international partnerships already helped stem violence improve security Haiti. Cite Soleil, example, no-man's-land years, today, violence subsided new sense freedom felt streets. The Haitian National Police supported work UN peacekeeping operation Haiti, first hemisphere Latin American Caribbean nations participated. Brazil led mission determination skill. This level engagement collaboration major step forward region. But criminal networks operating Haiti eliminated. Haiti continues fight drug traffickers made country distribution point illegal drugs headed United States, Canada Europe. Drug trafficking problem involves many nations, role play ending deadly trade. That includes United States. We give $2 million fight drug trafficking Haiti Merida Initiative, plan conceived Mexico, Central America United States. This money fund secure communications network Haitian police; provide maritime base, vehicles operational support police drug units; provide training promote cross-border cooperation Haiti Dominican Republic; sharpen investigation prosecution drug crimes. Once security established, opportunity take root. Nations Canada Spain Japan offered generous assistance help repair damage last year's storms. Now time take next step-to move beyond peacekeeping disaster relief long-term reconstruction development. Haiti highest unemployment rate hemisphere; 70 percent people don't jobs. It also one region's highest population growth rates. Together, trends created one development expert called "youth tsunami"-nearly 1 million youths expected come job market next five years. To spur creation jobs, United States passed HOPE Act 2006, give garments made Haiti tariff-free access U.S. market. Last October, extended trade preference another decade. Apparel one largest sectors Haiti's economy. We see great potential job creation field, gratified Brazil's interest supporting Haitian apparel industry well. But build diversified economy, Haiti needs trade deals. It also needs infrastructure support flow goods services. The roads Haiti beyond inadequate; many communities isolated lack passable road, prevents people holding jobs, children going school, farmers bringing crops market. Better roads could facilitate greater trade bring Haitians global economy. Haiti also needs better roads tourist areas, promote sector economy. Other urgent infrastructure needs include digging water catchments prevent floods, completing garment workers' training center, creating canals help irrigation. As part $287 million non-emergency assistance provide Haiti year, authorized $20 million aid generate jobs, help people put skills work building country's future. We look forward working Haiti distribute money quickly effectively, trigger virtuous circle long-term economic growth. All fiscal responsibility world can't prevent natural disaster. The hurricanes didn't wash away crops houses; also washed away months government planning future. Haiti facing approximately $50 million budget deficit, could undermine Haiti's long-term ambitions well services people depend survive. The United States provide $20 million pay Haiti's upcoming debt service obligations, free Haiti use resources fill budget gap. [There fourth urgent need United States committed helping Haiti resolve. The combined effect rising food prices globally destruction crops hurricanes exposed millions Haitians malnutrition destructive effects health productivity. Malnourished people often weak work; chronically hungry children struggle learn school. Food insecurity source suffering, direct threat economic growth global stability. The United States provide $15-million in-kind contribution food help Haiti continues rebuild. ] These ways United States ready partner Haiti nations. But additional pieces larger mission need support-from helping Haiti adapt climate change future hurricanes won't claim thousands lives; strengthening health systems; promoting sustainable agriculture; developing civil society. This work matter governments, also mission people. Here U.S., I heard many individuals groups care Haiti want help develop don't know invest time money way make real impact. We think creatively helping people outside government get involved meaningful way Haiti's future. Our people valuable resource, potential help places like Haiti yet tapped. We know empirical data small investments go long way. This something I've seen visits Haiti. I traveled husband shortly wedding, years later First Lady. I met doctor emigrated United States became U.S. Air Force Colonel, returned home town Pignon run center health, women's literacy microcredit. He staff resources, offered comprehensive range services thousands clients. I visited family-planning clinic young people trained educate peers protect health prevent teen pregnancy. And I met women group called Women Democracy. These women attended global conference women's leadership Montevideo, Uruguay, returned home, created organization support Haitian women running office. Eleven years later, organization larger stronger ever, mission. In addition supporting women candidates, also hold trade fairs women entrepreneurs, run civic education programs teach women rights, support women journalists, build connections women throughout Caribbean. These Haitian women remind us never achieve real progress leave millions people behind. And demonstrate powerful commitment part Haitian people participate lead nation's recovery. Our role support work however can, demonstrate actions belief future important own. What happens next Haiti send message world power collaboration behalf every poor nation worked hard earn foothold global economy tumbled recent months. On behalf every man woman hemisphere, northern expanses Canada southern tip Argentina, working harder ever fewer resources smaller rewards. children whose futures jeopardized forces far beyond control. let us prove commitment economic recovery reaches citizens individual nations people everywhere.
As often case, I read paper David rather learn home. . . perhaps I wouldn't way. cdm brifibinoton Post NEWSI POLITICSI OPINIONSI BUSINESSI LOCAL SPORTSI ARTS & LIVING I GOING OUT GUIDE I JOBSI CARSI REAL ESTATE 'SHOPPING School Second, Chances The teachers Oak Hill Academy approach jobs faith even hardened juvenile delinquents achieve -- knowledge many still won't By Karen Houppert Sunday, April 12, 2009; W18 The six teenage boys, incarcerated District's Oak Hill juvenile detention facility Laurel file classroom lunch one late January afternoon. They surprised see strangers -- five women two men -- sitting chairs boys typically occupy. The students find empty seats shrug matching brown coats mismatched scarves. They curious visitors lean-back, fold-your-arms, prove-it kind way. "I'm James Forman," begins 40-something man. "I'm professor Georgetown Law School -- " "You related James Forman?" interrupts 17-year-old Carleto Bailey. "I'm James Forman Jr." "That father? James Forman dad?" Carleto demands. "Yes, I " "Wasn't big civil rights guy? NAACP? Or SNCC?" "SNCC," Forman says, seemingly surprised Carleto heard father, executive secretary Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee years 1960s becoming active Black Panthers. B6 "He's good guy," Carleto continues. "You tell that." Forman smiles. "He passed years ago, would happy hear this," professor says. He scans room. The Oak Hill students, African American, dressed identically khaki pants royal-blue polo shirts. They chosen seats edges room and, sitting down, pushed chairs back far possible wall. Forman's Georgetown law students -- African American, Arab, Latino, Caucasian -- jeans sweaters. They lean forward, intent maybe little bit nervous. "I teach class juvenile justice law school," Forman continues. "And I thought would really good way law students learn juvenile justice. There certain amount learn reading, also need see experience things. So I thought would learn lot coming hearing experiences." Carleto raises eyebrow. This new one. "And benefit know things law don't. Ya'll certain things know. They certain things know. It learning opportunity everybody." Forman suggests go around room share names interesting fact themselves. Dead silence. He smiles encouragingly. "My name James Forman, I helped start organization, See Forever, runs school," says. Carleto, leaning back two rear legs chair, brings bang sends short dreads swinging forward black plastic rectangular glasses sliding nose. A Georgetown students jump. He looks top glasses. "My name's Carleto Bailey," says. "My interesting fact I'm funny./I He gives wide smile bright white teeth. The Georgetown students laugh. Oak Hill student Ashawntea Henderson, 17, sits next him, rolls eyes. But Carleto's done: "And I'm smart." But turns out, Georgetown folks -- like teachers Oak Hill Academy -- aren't going accept Carleto's assertion face value. They want good grades, right answers multiple-choice test. They want prove think. Forman shows group excerpt film juveniles incarcerated New York's Rikers Island. Afterward, law students want know whether label makes difference. It's hard question. "Inmates? Residents? Scholars?" one asks. "Does matter you're called?" Carleto studies woman's face discern wants hear back. It blank. He struggles. "Not much," says, finally. He looks her. She seems unconvinced. He worries given wrong answer tries again. "Back community, certain [police] patrols neighborhood say, 'I know you're to.' When come home, us trying right, basically criticize us you're already labeled." "What labels?" Forman asks. This one easy Carleto. He sinks chair throws out. "Trouble," says. *** Carleto Bailey trouble. He also, rightly noted, smart. But arrived Oak Hill Academy disadvantages: He poorly educated D.C. public schools, frequently truant multiple run-ins law. The D.C. Department Youth Rehabilitation Services, runs Oak Hill, won't release information specific crime landed Carleto still juvenile, know Carleto's second time detention center. His academic knowledge spotty best. He tell James Forman is, comma falls letter's greeting. ("Dear, Fidel" writes mock letter Castro English class.) He fairly typical Oak Hill "scholar." And, upon time, would written But today, staff fledgling Oak Hill Academy determined view kids' captive time window opportunity fill gaping holes education. Part reform initiative Vincent Schiraldi, director Youth Rehabilitation Services, school opened doors last year takes unique approach teaching delinquent youth. What would happen, Oak Hill Academy co-founders Forman David Domenici wondered, seduced kids content meaningful them? What would happen lots good, caring teachers small classrooms? What one assumed kids could learn -- behaved such? In words, would happen District's challenged students got private school education, albeit campus decidedly different nature? "The bottom line," says Domenici, "is kids risk need highest quality programming, they've gotten worst." It conviction drove Domenici, also school's principal, Forman create three public charter schools underprivileged troubled students District past 11 years. Called Maya Angelou schools, two high schools middle school attack educational deficiencies angles. Students attend small classes taught specially trained staff. The high school day stretches 9 a.m. 6 p.m., three meals provided. Some kids, whose home lives prove chaotic study, offered supervised housing neighborhood. And works. Last year, 93 percent Maya Angelou graduates accepted two- four-year colleges, Domenici says. (According District's Office State Superintendent Education, 29 percent students enter ninth grade D.C. public schools city charter schools enroll postsecondary educational programs within 18 months graduating high school.) It good model. But even though Domenici Forman used teaching court-involved youth -- 40 percent Maya Angelou students spent time Oak Hill -- working inside gates posed new set challenges. Youth Rehabilitation Services court monitor 23 years due part history abuse poor conditions. When Schiraldi took department 2005 began reform efforts implementing less punitive therapeutic detention model Oak Hill, saw immediately changing school essential. "How could I look staff Oak Hill say excellence kids sitting school total waste time 9 3 every day?" Schiraldi says. Kids sat watched movies day. Little, teaching going on, Schiraldi says. "It miserable, miserable school." Schiraldi immediately began lobbying D.C. Board Education hard hire someone new operate school, soon got okay, put request proposals. Domenici Forman submitted plan Schiraldi says "blew ones water," 2007 awarded $12 million contract run school next three years. Domenici's Forman's partnership somewhat unlikely one. Domenici son former New Mexico Republican senator Pete Domenici. He went Stanford Law School, worked corporate law years gave teach work teen delinquents. Forman grandson Jessica Mitford, daughter British baron celebrated civil rights activist journalist. Forman, graduated Yale Law School, worked law clerk Justice Sandra Day O'Connor D.C. public defender. After seeing good schooling options teenage clients had, joined forces Domenici, met mutual friend, start independent school 20 students 1997. A year later, became part first Maya Angelou public charter school. At Oak Hill Academy, principal Domenici fights occasionally maddening bureaucracy basics: functioning boilers, permission college tour group six students, classes uninterrupted corrections staff sometimes call three-quarters students middle class take meds. Forman chairman Maya Angelou Public Charter School Board Directors board member parent group, See Forever Foundation. He attacks hurdles side, fundraising advocating juvenile justice reform. "When David came run school here, like "Ocean's 12": Go find people trust previous mission," Forman jokes. That included past colleagues even Maya Angelou graduates. Samantha Crandal Simpore, then-coed Oak Hill 15 accessory assault charge, went Maya Angelou school runs Oak Hill Academy welcome center. "I tell them, I here, too," Simpore says. She tells new student 17 years old didn't know multiplication tables, rode bus school day hooked Walkman, hoping one knew listening recitation times tables. "I say: 'You're intersection life. You know what's street behind you. Nothing that. But choice what's road ahead.'" Many 90 Oak Hill students, ranging age 14 19, come performing way grade level, nearly half diagnosed learning disabilities. They Oak Hill average 10 months, cycling schedule nothing nine-month academic year. Out necessity, grouped according cell blocks live keep opposing gangs separate. Thirteen-year-olds classes 18-year-olds. More half committed Oak Hill violent felonies. Fights common. (Before month out, Carleto get fistfight hallway delay release date.) Through use small classes -- typically five 14 teens work one teacher, teaching assistant guard -- school organizes curriculum around four-week themes designed pique students' curiosity get think critically nature democracy, social justiCe role world. For example, Relationship theme, students parse types relationships ranging humans natural world (ancient river civilizations) individuals groups (Pharaohs subjects) humans ideas (liberation theology). At time, English class, students working standard five-paragraph essay via guiding question: "Why relationships matter, relationships good bad people?" With current unit, Change, D.C. public school system's learning standards woven social studies curriculum loose headings "Changes Way Humans Think About World Their Place It," becomes way introducing scientific revolution, Enlightenment Magna Carta. It's philosophy emphasizes learning making cross-discipline connections long popular affluent, progressive schools typically eschewed schools underprivileged kids, rote learning return basics often rule. Oak Hill Academy also created course called Advocacy, Georgetown law students co- teaching, emphasizing month's theme. Domenici believes learning law works democracy "is essential teaching good citizens." "We always believed one roles help kids self-advocate advocate behalf community," Domenici says. "We think good skill students individually also one democracy demands." But ambitious agenda, Oak Hill Academy faces significant obstacles. Can teach teens think critically they're missing basic underpinnings education? How teach empowerment setting demands rigid compliance keep kids misbehaving? Although sometimes grows discouraged, Domenici best buoy staff members learn one promising students got fight unit "graduated" program commit another crime sent back. "I talk staff fact that, day day, job absolute best work domain within control," says, reminding don't control pieces puzzle. "And well, done moral thing." His staff members must keep faith straddling two equally potent realities: First, knowledge power, possessing it, every student capable success. And, absent right support, failure lurks right around corner. It sounds like this: "I think Carleto good chance finishing high school going college," Domenici says. Pause. "Also, highly risk that." *** It cold day late January, Oak Hill midst four-week session change. Dressed jeans, blue shirt gray corduroy jacket (the heat's working), Oak Hill social studies teacher John Adams paces around room stops bend Carleto, doodling piece paper desk. "Pay attention," says, taking Carleto's pencil. "Carleto, today's essential question?" "What historical change, different kinds change?" Carleto says, reading board Adams scrawled topic. "Yes," Adams says. He ignores student wandering around room aimlessly, student snatches hat classmate tosses toward hallway. A youth development specialist, corrections guards referred Schiraldi, appears deeply engrossed magazine back room. But snatches hat mid-air, scowls disruptive student tucks hat pocket. "Please sit," Adams tells student. Not quite sitting, quite standing, student perches edge Adams's desk. Good enough. Adams continues: "What's difference personal change historical change?" Silence. "Anybody? More silence. "Ashawntea?" "Historical change like revolution," Ashawntea says. Adams throws list changes -- getting raise salary, moving new house, election President Obama -- Carleto accurately sorts changes micro macro, personal historical. "Obama's campaign change," Adams says. "Do think talking historical change?" He wants students think president, office two days. What might first 100 days look like? asks students. "What advice would offer him?" Carleto looks stumped. "Just throw ideas," Adams prompts. He tells students going craft letters president, advising set agenda change. Carleto slaps pencil desk. "Obama's reading letters," says. He folds arms across chest, skeptical president lay eyes letter -- skeptical, perhaps, teachers really want hear ideas. *** Later, Carleto acknowledge knows quite bit president, reading Barack Obama's "Dreams From My Father." "It started good book, got excellent," says. He struggles hard articulate book's themes appeal. "I don't know put it," says finally, "but growing -- disrespect, -- Caucasian mom African father, still made through." Sitting guard's room gym February evening, echoing sound classmates bouncing basketballs around cavernous gym, Carleto goes tell possibly apocryphal story. "As child, fun, happy -- far kindergarten sixth grade. Starting first grade, honor roll also making school every day," says, beginning third person, quickly lapsing first. "In late stages middle school; end eighth grade, I started smoking weed, stuff I wasn't supposed doing." He takes full responsibility. "No one peer-pressured anything. I liking going I high," explains. He, like almost teens Oak Hill, denies involved gang. Still, Carleto says best friend since elementary school killed 10th grade "a neighborhood thing." "Nowadays, anyone ride you, mistaken someone else shot," says, explaining buddy shot "miscommunication." "It wasn't intended us," says, insisting friend, nicknamed "Smoke," waiting bus. Then announces, "I don't want talk it." So doesn't, though clearly haunts him: He doodle "R.I.P. Smoke" cover blue folder piece loose-leaf paper comer chalkboard. He's happy talk Oak Hill Academy though, 3.5 grade-point average six months. (Domenici says Carleto top 25 percent students Oak Hill tests fairly high assessments.) Carleto likes school even though bit easy him, senior freshman. He complains classes short guards always interrupting move class getting warmed up. That really bugs him, doesn't say much. He says leaving Oak Hill two months intends finish schooling Oak Hill's transition center District, says graduate June. When gets out, couple things wants right off, says. First, intends see girlfriend, go restaurant go "the Adidas shop Georgetown, mom get stuff-- dad, too." He says mom pretty upset got arrested sent Oak Hill. "She was. . . I'm going say kind like surprised actions, I done," Carleto says. "You know say 'Whatever hides dark, comes out?'. . . She ashamed me, disappointed me." Meanwhile, makes long, 45-minute trek District Laurel visit. "Every weekend, days!" says. He alternately vague specific describes family life. He four brothers -- ages 27, 23, 16 11 -- reports two younger brothers live mom. He says mom works secretary, struggles remember where. "She working with, what's program downtown Washington Monument, dealing Smokey Bear?. . . I'm trying think. It's right Holocaust Museum. It's brick building. She works there." Later, Carleto's school case worker, Essence Jones, offer somewhat different account Carleto's life. Although Carleto 12th grade, graduate June says. He still six credits shy, Jones says. And least three months -- two -- release. Carleto's father part life, Jones says. The teenager living aunt coming Oak Hill. His mother, rap sheet dating 1982, jail years, arrested repeatedly string felonies misdemeanors, including possession distribution drugs, well prostitution. She prison since 2005, serving three consecutive sentences totaling seven years assault dangerous weapon, attempted distribution cocaine violation bail. She visiting Carleto weekends. *** By end February, still midst unit change, Oak Hill teens file advocacy class, jostling other, edgy. It unseasonably warm outside, want here. Reluctantly take seats, Carleto positions see patch brown grass mud prison yard, visible door someone wedged open. Occasionally, breeze wafts room. Today, law students decide tackle topic disproportionate minority confinement. If youths color 35 percent general population United States, 62 percent prison population, disproportionate minority confinement, law students explain. They refer teens handout desk front him, article excerpt New American Media, "Racism Juvenile Justice System Revealed," explain isn't simply people color commit crimes: "African-American youths 4.5 times likely, Latinos 2.3 times likely, white youths detained identical offenses. About half white teenagers arrested drug charge go home without formally charged drawn system. Only one-quarter black teens arrested drug charges catch similar break." Although youth color 100 percent Oak Hill's population inmates and, indeed, 100 percent 721 juvenile delinquents currently committed Youth Rehabilitation Services care settings across city, disproportionate minority confinement hard concept teens grasp. Georgetown student Abby Fee tries pie graph, bar graph, sketch disproportionate Xs Os. Blank stares. Then slowly dawns Ashawntea they're talking about. "Hey," says, suddenly sitting forward. "They're switched around! Basically, there's us juveniles prison white juveniles -- even though there's them." "Yes," Fee says. "So population outside system looks lot different inside system." Ashavvntea sits back chair mull over. Fee law students move teens statistics speculative discussion reasons behind figures. They prepared role-playing game coax teens thinking different perspectives. Then, want students practice advocating change. "So, we're going three roles," Fee says, dividing teens pairs. "One group 15-year-old; one group playing math teacher; one group playing city council member." Carleto partner learn play city council member preparing presentation reforming police department. Carleto doesn't want city council member. He doesn't even want today. He wraps unwraps pencil bottom T-shirt. He puts glasses on, takes off. "How could maintain better relationships" police? Fee asks, settling chair help Carleto partner work this. Carleto throws pencil table. Won't answer. She asks again. Silence. Finally, offers sullen challenge. "Stop harassing people reason?" "How want treat people?" "Equally," says. He picks pencil tap, tat, taps desk. Fee tries get specific. "Don't arrest small problems. Instead, take home, tell family you're doing," Carleto's partner says, unconsciously slipping second person. "And think help crime stopped decreased general?" Fee prods. A long pause. Could minds whirring busily; could they're spacing out. Fee, teacher enrolling Georgetown, takes stride. She taps paper couple times repeats question. "Don't 10 15 cars patrolling area barely see police car," Carleto says. "Patrol ward equally?" asks Fee. Carleto writes down, adds: "I see lot cruel things done ain't right." Fee nods, encourages write down. Carleto's partner grabs pencil speaks writes. "The majority police shouldn't carry guns. I could say, 'The majority police racist.'" "But would fix that?" Fee. prods. "A camera car catch they're -- secret one," Carleto suggests. He sits straighter chair. "And don't pull people they're black. They say anything, that's reason I pulled over, headlights whatever." Suddenly, Carleto roll, rattles list improvements. "Call order city council," says Georgetown student Dania Ayoubi. Carleto partner stand front class. "Hello, I'm Mr. Jones, I city councilman," Carleto says, glancing paper twisting tail shirt free hand. "We complaints different communities wards police, suggestions cracking officers." He sounds nervous begins list. "Stop harassing minorities ethnic youths, treat equal race are. Also, police don't arrest situation school like fight anything. I feel arrested taken home. Then tell parents happened reason stopped police." He moves briskly suggestions twice, tentatively, tries actually making eye contact audience. In conclusion, says, "verbally abusing" youth won't tolerated more. "Basically, want crack officers removed, so." Another pair students rises begin presentation, teens interrupted crackle guard's walkie-talkie. "Time go!" guard announces. The law students surprised -- quite done -- politely acquiesce. "Wait!" Ashawntea says, standing up. "We got 10 minutes." "It take five minutes get stuff together get coats on," guard says. "But 10 minutes!" Carleto insists. He Ashawntea sit back fold arms. "It's 2:20. We got 10 minutes still." The guard takes beat, shrugs concedes Carleto's point. He goes back hall wait. Carleto shoots Ashawntea look surprise. His advocacy worked. "Yesss!" Ashawntea hisses breath. April 25, 2009 Clinton, Iraq, Blames 'Rejectionists' Violence By MARK LANDLER BAGHDAD — Secretary State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived Saturday morning one-day visit, delivering American show support Iraq battles sudden eruption violence, wake suicide bombings killed least 140 people wounded several hundred Thursday Friday. Mrs. Clinton, first visit Baghdad secretary state, acknowledged attacks worrisome. She said would seek briefing security situation American military commander, Gen. Ray Odierno, first meeting Saturday, day packed appointments. But played suggestions attacks augured return relentless sectarian violence convulsed Iraq 2006. She said signal new jihadist movement taking root Iraq, could derail progress country made last two years. "In Iraq, always political conflicts," Mrs. Clinton said reporters setting unannounced visit Friday evening. "But I really believe Iraq, whole, right track." She characterized latest bout violence last gasp "rejectionists" fear government succeed creating united peaceful Iraq. The suicide bombings, said, "in unfortunately tragic way, signal rejectionists fear Iraq going right direction." "Are going bad days? Yes, are," Mrs. Clinton said. But added, "If look evidence, overwhelmingly progress that's made positive." The Obama administration, said, determined help Iraq achieve "stability, sovereignty, self-reliance," United States prepares pull last troops end 2011. Mrs. Clinton regular visitor here, coming three times senator chart progress war voted authorize, later said mismanaged Bush administration. She said pleased back, though attacks cast shadow visit. While violence far worst levels 2006, 18 major attacks month kindled fears Baathist jihadist elements could reconstituting smaller, still deadly, insurgency exploit withdrawal American troops 2011. Mrs. Clinton compared latest suicide bombings spectacular terrorist attack occurred several months Good Friday peace accord ended years conflict Northern Ireland. At times, analysis almost echoed former Vice President Dick Cheney former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld. When sectarian violence relentless several years ago, Mr. Cheney spoke insurgency "last throes," Mr. Rumsfeld talked "dead-enders" kept fighting lost cause. On Friday, Gen. David Petraeus, head military's Central Command, testified House appropriations committee suicide bombers may part militant network based Tunisia. Four bombers, said, Tunisia. Mrs. Clinton said specific information bombers, said: "We've seen suicide bombers many countries Iraq last six years. It's unfortunate young men, occasionally even young woman, would travel Iraq kill people way." 41 The violence seem curtail Mrs. Clinton's ambitions brief visit. In addition General Odierno, scheduled meet retinue Iraqi leaders, including president, Jalal Talabani; prime minister, Nuni Kamal al- Maliki; foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari. She also playing host roundtable Iraqi women, something done previous trips Iraq. And hold town-hall meeting Iraqi students, well members nongovernmental organizations provincial reconstruction teams. This format Mrs. Clinton savored presidential candidate, that, secretary state, used South Korea Turkey. "I want listen," said, "I want respond questions concerns. I want feedback ideas going make transition successful possible." When President Obama visited Baghdad earlier month, dusty skies prevented traveling helicopter Baghdad International Airport city. He met Mr. Maliki palace near airport General Odierno American base, Camp Victory. The new American ambassador, Christopher R. Hill, beat Mrs. Clinton Baghdad one day. He confirmed Senate Tuesday lengthy process held Republican senators, objected lack experience Arab world handling negotiations North Korea nuclear weapons program. In Iraq, Mr. Hill spearhead shift emphasis United States military civilian operations. Some Iraq experts said American civilian presence lacking momentum since departure February last United States ambassador, Ryan C. Crocker.
Clinton says Iraq right track BAGHDAD (AP) - U.S. Secretary State Hillary Rodham Clinton says week's deadly suicide bombings Iraq sign extremists fear Iraqi government succeeding. On first visit Iraq America's top diplomat, Clinton said country made tremendous strides despite recent violence continues deserve support Obama administration moves reduce U.S. military presence there. Clinton arrived Baghdad Saturday unannounced trip suicide bombings capital outside killed least 148 people Thursday Friday. The attacks exposed gaps security Iraq takes U.S. forces protecting country.

In Obama Administration, use smart power advance shared security, shared prosperity shared humanity. In advancing shared security, seek to: • Reduce threat violent extremism • Reduce spread weapons mass destruction In advancing shared prosperity, seek to: • Use development create sustain strong stable economies by: o Focusing women essential driving economic growth; o Expanding access food means grow buy it; and, o Expanding access quality education developing countries; • Expand access stable, affordable increasingly clean energy sources In advancing shared humanity, seek to: • Expand human rights conditions promote respect human rights • Support development health systems support healthier societies confront spread pandemic disease (e.g., AlDs) How achieve goals: We advance goals shared responsibility application smart power. America responsibility lead, lead partnership others. Smart power means elevating integrating diplomacy development. U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE Office Spokesman For Immediate Release June 2, 2009 2009/ Question Taken June 1, 2009 Daily Press Briefing Current results Texting Campaign Humanitarian Aid Pakistan Q. How much money raised texting campaign humanitarian aid Pakistan? A. The United Nations High Commissioner Refugees reported June 1, 2009, total $135,008 private donations U.S. sources humanitarian aid Pakistan received. Of total, $31,390 received via 5,722 text messages. The remainder included $84,702 received via 439 online donations; $18,916 mail major donors. # # #

Barack Obama may support insurance mandate By CARRIE BUDOFF BROWN I 6/3/09 3:42 PM EDT Updated: 6/3/09 11:22 PM EDT As presidential candidate, Barack Obama scoffed Hillary Rodham Clinton's proposal require people buy health insurance. "(If) can't afford it, don't get it," Obama said primary, arguing mandate would work unless insurance costs lowered first. For first time, Obama confirmed Wednesday plans stake different position president. In letter two leading Democratic senators, Obama said could support mandate individuals buy coverage, long Congress exempted could afford it. This marks shift stance campaign, tussled repeatedly Clinton issue. She proposed individual mandate, not. "I share goal ending lapses gaps coverage make us less healthy drive everyone's costs, I open ideas shared responsibility," Obama wrote. "But I believe going make people responsible owning health insurance, must make health care affordable." "If end system people responsible insurance, need provide hardship waiver exempt Americans cannot afford it," Obama wrote. Detailing positions various health care proposals first time president, Obama also said Americans able choose public private insurance plans reformed health care system. "I strongly believe Americans choice public health insurance option operating alongside private plans," wrote. "This give better range choices, make health care market competitive, keep insurance companies honest." He offered qualified support mandate employers provide insurance pay fee government. Employers "have responsibility support health insurance employees," Obama wrote, small businesses exempt. Obama's positions issues entirely surprising, decision weigh congressional Democratic leaders released single bill unexpected. Prior letter, Obama aides declined say specifically stood various issues, including public plan individual mandate, saying wanted Congress lead way writing bill. But Democrats anxious president take public stance, letter provides guidance many Congress craving House Senate committees move closer releasing draft bills. "The president says get done. Get done right get one chance," said Sen. Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.), member Senate Health, Education, Labor Pensions Committee. "The letter essentially synthesizes president saying." He outlined parameters letter Senate Finance Chairman Max Baucus (D-Mont.) Health, Education, Labor Pensions Committee Chairman Ted Kennedy (D-Mass.). Obama's endorsement public insurance option could boost controversial proposal serve catalyst Democratic base president kicks grassroots campaign Saturday. "It's clear Republican resistance public plan hasn't softened President Obama's support one," Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said statement. "This strengthens hand us advocating public option, way keep private insurers' feet fire." Despite almost uniform opposition Republicans public plan, president wrote letter remains "hopeful many Republicans" would back overhaul bill. Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), ranking Republican Finance Committee, struck optimistic tone statement, saying letter "doesn't draw lines sand," "is helpful statements reform legislation needs bipartisan support." However, letter likely incite opponents, frustrated Obama's lack specifics. Indeed, Thursday morning, Conservatives Patients' Rights begin airing new TV ad called "Bulldozer," says "government-run plan" drive private insurers business eliminate consumer choices. By MATTHEW LEE WASHINGTON (AP) — Secretary State Hillary Rodham Clinton soon announce gay American diplomats given benefits similar heterosexual counterparts enjoy, U.S. officials said Saturday. In notice sent soon State Department employees, Clinton says regulations denied same-sex couples families rights privileges straight diplomats enjoyed "unfair must end," harm U.S. diplomacy. "Providing training, medical care benefits domestic partners promote cohesiveness, safety effectiveness posts abroad," says message, copy obtained The Associated Press. "It also help department attract retain personnel competitive environment domestic partner benefits allowances increasingly norm world-class employers," says. "At bottom, department provide benefits opposite-sex same-sex domestic partners right thing do," Clinton says. Among benefits granted gay diplomats: right domestic partners hold diplomatic passports, government-paid travel partners families foreign posts, use U.S. medical facilities abroad. In addition, gay diplomats' families eligible U.S. government emergency evacuations training courses Foreign Service Institute, message says. The announcement, expected week, provided AP State Department official member Gays Lesbians Foreign Affairs Agencies organization. Two department officials affiliated organization confirmed accuracy. The officials spoke condition anonymity authorized speak publically changes.

FYI CQ TODAY ONLINE NEWS — APPROPRIATIONS June 4, 2009 — 1:39 p.m. War Supplemental Conference Slips Next Week By Josh Rogin, CQ Staff House leadership decided hold conference vote war supplemental spending bill week, leaders worked behind scenes secure enough Democratic votes pass measure absent GOP support. Multiple lawmakers aides confirmed expected Thursday session finalize negotiations bill (HR 2346), mainly fund wars Iraq Afghanistan, occur least early next week. Democratic leaders trying convince many 18 51 Democrats voted House version May change votes, many said would so. Republicans promising vote conference report en mass includes $5 billion worth funding related International Monetary Fund. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said Thursday would. "I believe people Republican Party support [the IMF funding]; don't want support bill," Pelosi said Thursday, "So Democratic votes." She also pushed back two key pillars House Republican leadership's argument IMF funding, meant accommodate increased U.S. credit extension organization. Responding statements Minority Leader John A. Boehner Ohio IMF money unrelated war spending measure, Pelosi said IMF help "national security initiative" helps alleviate sources instability, poverty. Pelosi also accused House Minority Whip Eric Cantor, R-Va., fear mongering putting statement warning IMF assistance could somehow fund terrorism. "I don't know anyone would say money going hands terrorists," said. "It simply based fact scare tactic, unfortunate." House Democratic aides said conference supplemental bill probably would early next week. "We're going come supplemental conference report next days," said Senate Majority leader Harry Reid, D-Nev. 6 Whipping Votes House leaders planned hold conference session Thursday said House floor vote could early Friday. But effort convince members switch votes still underway Thursday afternoon. • Although several high ranking Democrats pledged switch votes, including Reps. Barney Frank, D-Mass., George Miller, D-Calif., many others said would not. "It's conscience vote," said Rep. Alan Grayson, D-Fla., said inclined change stance bill "I haven't cracked yet," said Rep. Jim McGovern, D-Mass., along anti-war Democrats pledged war funding provide withdrawal troops southwest Asia. Still, many Democrats said leadership lobbying relatively intensely. More Details Emerge Meanwhile, details near finalized supplemental conference report negotiations came Thursday. Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Daniel K. Inouye, D-Hawaii, said final bill "in likelihood" include money 5 C-130 transport planes 8 C-17 cargo planes, none requested administration Senate's bill. The House bill sought 11 C-130s 8 C-17s. Overall, defense portion bill expected $4 billion less House version still billions Senate version administration request, House Appropriations Defense subcommittee chairman John P. Murtha, D-Pa., said. As fate prisoners Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, conference report likely include language barring administration transferring prisoners U.S. soil remainder fiscal year, said House Appropriator James P. Moran, D-Va. No money towards president's effort close prisons conference report, Moran added. The president requested $80 million neither House Senate versions included funds. Rooney) June 6,2009 11:30am Rooney (x7-7203, CONCEPT NOTE FOR WORLD FOOD PRIZE CEREMONY Thursday, June 11, 2009 This speech opportunity signal urgency problem global hunger; connect array global issues, including economic development, health education, expanding opportunity women, political stability; declare Administration's commitment tackling hunger roots, effective efficient collaboration array partners. Additionally, remarks point shift past approaches emphasizing need support local solutions focus long-term sustainability help people feed reduce need emergency assistance road. The speech could framed follows: THE PRIZE AND PRIZE-WINNER You begin announcing winner 2009 World Food Prize, Dr. Gebisa Ejeta. He remarkable story: born mud hut Ethiopia, got PhD Purdue University plant breeding genetics developed strains sorghum drought-tolerant, high-yield, resistant Striga weed, devastates crops across Africa. Outside lab, helped start Sudanese commercial seed industry; developed systems produce, certify, market hybrid seeds; educated farmers use fertilizers soil water conservation. And trained inspired next generation African agricultural scientists. A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH: FROM LAB TO FARM TO MARKET TO TABLE Dr. Ejeta's work reflects breadth issue comprehensive approach needed address it—one connects labs new seed technologies developed.., fields small-scale farmers labor feed families make living.., markets food bought sold... homes people get nourishment need thrive. In many places, food chain broken. One billion people worldwide woke hungry morning go sleep hungry tonight. Chronic hunger threatens health, making harder people work students learn, turn stunts economic development. Last year's food riots demonstrated food scarce, political stability threatened. 44 To date, world's primary response hunger send emergency food aid. While saves lives, short-term fix, need long-term solution. The Obama Administration committed leading developing new global approach. We support creation sustainable agricultural systems appropriate regions around world, increase agricultural productivity, create jobs, strengthen economies, protect natural resources. We imposing one-size-fits-all solutions, assisting countries carrying individual strategies meet needs—for example, Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Plan. To facilitate coordination share best practices, seek convene donor governments, multilateral institutions, NG0s, private companies, foundations, universities, individuals. THE ANCHORS OF OUR APPROACH We've identified seven anchors secure sustainable agriculture systems. These guide approach. • Increase agricultural productivity expanding access quality seeds, fertilizer, irrigation, credit purchase them, training use them. • Stimulate post-harvest sector improving storage processing food improving transportation connect small farmers markets. • Maintain natural resources land farmed well future make right adaptations changing environment. • Expand knowledge training support R&D developing next generation agriculture scientists. • Increase trade small-scale farmers developing countries sell crops far wide. • Support policy reform good governance, sustainable agriculture flourishes clear predictable policy regulatory environment. • Support women families agriculture. Seventy percent world's farmers women, programs offer credit training farmers target men. This must change agriculture thrive. And children must nutrition contribute communities' future. A PREVIEW OF WHAT'S TO COME In coming weeks, President Obama, Secretary Vilsack I reaching share approach global coordination agriculture greater detail. We seek input, wisdom guidance working long arena—from Congress NGOs academics foundations private sector. The President's conversations G-8 meeting Italy two weeks address approach, well trip Africa August. Addressing hunger food essential achieving economic recovery, stabilizing societies, expanding opportunity hundreds millions people worldwide. This supporting sustainable agriculture worldwide central element foreign policy Obama Administration. CONCLUSION You circle back story Dr. Ejeta close. FYI, Gary Sick's latest analysis Iran (posted blog). Sick independent sources well informed. June 17, 2009 Is another Iranian revolution? To someone watched studied Iranian revolution 1979 fascination, developments Iran today eerie reminiscence. Then massive protests filled streets, often marching dignified ominous silence; bloodshed nervous security men guns faced determined unarmed crowds; sullen mourning parades;20there catchy chants ritual calls "Down shah!"; night rooftops rang shouts allahu akbar. You need change "shah" "dictator," description happening Iran today. But one big difference. Thirty years ago, Iran charismatic cleric named Ayatollah Khomeini refined sense strategy willingness risk everything cause represented. On side Mohammed Reza Shah, throne 37 years commanded one powerful military security regimes world. On surface appeared uneven battle — guns turbans — ruler guns wavered turbans grew size confidence old order collapsed. Today nominal leader opposition forces reformed radical, Mir Hossein Mousavi, notably lacking personal charisma. On side constitutional Leader, Ayatollah IChamene' i, widely perceived cautious political animal limited qualifications religious post compensates lack charisma manipulation political system institutions loyal — particularly politically minded clergy powerful security forces, including Revolutionary Guards. Neither men seems fully control forces, let alone situation. The fraudulent election defeat Mousavi triggering event, energy behind unprecedented demonstrations due sense outrage betrayal gross manipulation numbers regime undying devotion Mousavi. Yesterday Mousavi ordered people stay home face conflicting pro-regime demonstration. They marched anyway (and daughter former president Rafsanjani joined urged on). Mousavi "ordered" everyone march following day (which probably going without orders). IChamene'i announced "divine assessment" election outcome — even would probably physically possible count 40 million ballots. Then, face mass protests, ordered investigation results Guardian Council— organization responsible managing election first place. No one believed either case, one expected anything importance Guardian Council. Khamene'i ordered peace reconciliation. No one paid attention. I deliberately mention president-elect Ahmadinejad. After celebrating "victory," went largely symbolic meeting Moscow. He seems decision loop passive player major actor events. So calling shots? Mousavi seems running along crowd, leading it. But probably required keep protest motion. On side, little evidence suggests important decisions made ultra-conservative leadership Revolutionary Guards, whose political role ballooned past decade, perhaps cooperation extremist counterparts clergy. They utterly ruthless ideologically fueled. New York Times columnist Nick Kristoff reminded us several days ago (see blog item June 15 below) end day, I saw Tiananmen 20 years ago, Might Right battle, it's often prudent bet Might, least short run. The regime seems miscalculated badly. They seemed believe sudden coup — announcement dramatic election results followed show force — would intimidate silence opposition consolidate control. That perhaps understandable decisions made military leaders tend see battle Manichaean terms, rather politicians IChamene'i accustomed seeing shades gray. In event, b ackfired much larger crisis hands simply arranged Ahmadinejad win slim margin (which least believable). All parties uncharted territory. A significant portion Iranian population seems concluded social contract rulers — accepting Islamic rule return respectful regard opinion governed, Islamic Republic — longer valid. They trust rulers. The rulers, whose support declining years face inept management country, increasingly replacing popular support repression. This election seems called tactic question. For military, obvious answer repression. So would appear moment bet Might. But nobody fully command events. Decisions taken next weeks fateful could determine future path Iranian revolution. There another lesson Iran's leaders contemplate Tiananmen moment. When Tiananmen crackdown occurred almost exactly ten years ago, one leaders China time Zhao Ziyang, General Secretary Communist Party. He later fired placed house arrest. His smuggled memoirs appeared, revealing depth disagreements within lea dership proceed. Is possible ten years volume describing intense debates one presume underway today highest councils Islamic Republic Iran? Dell Days Deals! June 15-24 - A New Deal Everyday!
Thursday, June 18, 2009 Day Mourning, Protests, Called Mousavi Thursday Mir-Hosain Mousavi, maintains won last Friday's presidential election despite official assertions lost 2 1 Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, calling another rally Thursday, time part honor persons killed hardliners security forces course previous demonstrations. Mourning martyr central Iranian Shiite religious culture strains medieval Catholicism Europe, Mousavi's camp tapping powerful set images myths here. The archetypal Shiite martyr Imam Husayn, grandson Prophet Muhammad, championed oppressed Muslims Iraq cut Umayyad Muslim Empire. Redognition Muslim state might commit ultimate sacrilege beheading person dangled Prophet's knee imbued modern political Shiism distrust state. When Husayn's head brought Umayyad caliph Yazid deposited throne, older companions Prophet said wept remarked, "I saw Prophet's lips cheeks." Shiites ritually march, flagellate, chant honor martyred Imam divinely-appointed leader. Today's protesters wearing green, symbolizes Mousavi's descent Prophet Muhammad. (Mousavi's family name refers Seventh Imam (descendant Prophet claims divine knowledge), Musa Kazim, whose tomb Kazimiya, north Baghdad. Sayyid families, claiming descent Prophet, often take one Imams' names family name honor them, though course also claiming descent previous Imams right back Prophet.) The repertoires protest reformists using echo 1978-79 Islamic Revolution-- chanting "God Great," mourning pious fallen martyrs, etc.-- another sign movement alienated secularized elites. But Mousavi's supporters also sporting black ribbons indicate mourning fallen. Typically, dead commemorated one month 40 days. In 1978 demonstrations killed previous demonstrations grew size year, till reached alleged million streets Tehran. Since reformists already claiming Monday's rally million, wonder things go here. The regime's attempt paint protesters nothing US intelligence agents underlines wise President Obama insert forcefully situation Iran. The reformers hard liners stable groupings. The core competing allegiance general Iranian public. If reformers convince Iranians justice cause, swing behind opposition. If hard liners convince public reformers nothing cat's paws grasping, imperialist West-- i.e. Ahmad Chalabis trying bring Iran foreign occupation get power themselves-- reformists crushed. Iranians value national independence all, suffered CIA-installed goverment decades mid-twentieth century. The prescriptions John McCain Faux Cable news muscular US diplomacy point tone deaf Iranian realities would backfire big time, harming reform cause US interests. Anyway, basket case US Republican Party reduced Iraq, one global South likely want meddling internal affairs. Reports streaming arrest hundred opposition figures hard line militia men following protesters home breaking homes terrorize them. See e.g., Basij paramilitary forces terrorize residential complex. The Basij militiamen said afraid come numbers opposition demonstrations, sneak around night trail protesters harass arrest them. Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei met Tuesday morning representatives four presidential candidates, urging make continuing insist Alunadinejad winner 24 million 14 million votes. He portrayed massive post-election demonstrations charges ballot fraud minor tiff. Gary Sick wonders Khamenei really supreme leader more, hints hard line tack stealing election directed Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps, country's religious national guard. Reports coming Iran allege regime tracking destroying satellite dishes, using helicopters aerial surveillance neighborhoods Basij, right wing militia (sort like Mussolini's Black Shirts) breaking entering. Sid 5ousavi's New Revolutionary Manifesto Gary Sick June 21, 2009 I 10:51am — L Alfred, Sipa / AP Photo The Iranian protest movement reached tipping point today, writes Gary Sick, • key White House offical 1979 hostage crisis, emerged nothing short platform true Islamic democracy. Plus, read insight Iran's election Daily Beast writers. Today, Mir Hossein Mousavi, presidential candidate come represent democratic aspirations Iranian people, issued formal statement. Although denounces "lies fraud" leadership, particularly recent election, views fraudulent election symptom something far serious. He describes revolution gone wrong, revolution originally based attention voice peo ple resulted "forcing unwanted government nation." It apparent statement Mousavi's movement—and Mousavi himself—have evolved enormously past week. This moment "a turning point," says, defines movement forming around "historical mission" accomplish nothing less "renewing life nation" according ideals. He acknowledges, interestingly, voice beginning less "eloquent" would wished people ahead turning movement green. But accepts "burden duty put shoulders destiny generations ages." He denounces extremes political spectrum: one hand believe "Islamic government Tyranny Rightful;" other, "consider religion Islam blockers realization republicanism," i.e. believe democracy incompatible Islam. Mousavi says call annulment election revote, supervised impartial national body, "is given right." The objective nothing less "to achieve new type political life country." That truly revolutionary statement. He says stand side seeking "new solutions" n on-violent way. He accepts principles institutions Islamic Republic, including Revolutionary Guard basij, denounces "deviations deceptions." He demands reform "that returns us pure principles Islamic Revolution." He calls freedom expression forms, says government permits people express views freely, "there won't need presence military regulatory forces streets." It apparent statement Mousavi's movement—and Mousavi himself—have evolved enormously past week. The candidate started mild-mannered reformer. After searing events past several days, dared preach counter sermon Khamene'i's lecture Islamic government. Although never mentions Leader name, overlooking direct contradiction arguments. Longtime Clinton confidant Blumenthal become Clinton advisor Tue, 06/23/2009 - 1:00pm Longtime journalist former Clinton White House advisor Sidney Blumenthal become special advisor without portfolio Secretary State Hillary Clinton, The Cable learned. Blumenthal refused comment. But sources say filling paperwork disentangling obligations moves become special advisor secretary whose presidential campaign helped advise. The position would require Senate confirmation. Clinton, recovering surgery repair broken elbow, building team State Department, establishing credentials team player supporting amplifying former presidential rival's foreign-policy vision. Sources close says prove indispensable Obama, point several Obama aides also made Politico's Ben Smith piece noting relatively background role played early months. The planned addition Blumenthal, longtime confidant Clinton family fierce defender Bill Clinton's presidential legacy, could indicate plans raise profile. (Blumenthal probably Clinton's best speechwriter, friend notes.) In foreign-policy arena, Blumenthal advised former President Clinton U.S.-British relations, first introduced future British Prime Minister Tony Blair. He also active Third Way- Progressive Governance process. A former Washington Post reporter, Blumenthal contributed commentary editorial advice Vanity Fair, Tina Brown's new online magazine The Daily Beast, New Yorker, Salon. Blumenthal also fellow New York University's Center Law Security. Laura Rozen I Permalink I fA9ç%'1 Comments? Login register 52

This President Obama's lowest approval rating national statewide Quinnipiac University poll since inaugurated 62 - 31 percent May 6 survey. By small 48 - 46 percen margin, voters disapprove way Obama handling economy, independent Quinnipiac (KWIN-uh-pe-ack) University poll finds. This 57 - 36 percent approval May 6. A total 66 percent Ohio voters "somewhat dissatisfied" "very dissatisfied" way things going state, 33 percent "very satisfied" "somewhat satisfied," numbers haven't changed since Obama elected. In race Ohio's U.S. Senate seat vacated retiring George Voinovich 2010, Lee Fisher Jennifer Brunner remain neck-and-neck Democratic nomination would defeat GOP candidates election today. "The economy Ohio bad anywhere America. These numbers indicate first time voters decided President Barack Obama bears responsibility problems," said Peter A. Brown, assistant director Quinnipiac University Polling Institute. "Until voters given President Obama high ratings economy, blaming former President George W. Bush problems. They might taking frustration President Obama, possibly deciding change promised come quickly expected." "Ohio historically prototypical swing state. One reasons Barack Obama won p residency wide margin carried Ohio 52 percent vote captured lion's share independent votes," Brown added. "Now, 48 - 46 percent margin, Ohio independent voters give President failing grade economy. These numbers indicate may losing, least now, voted November indication White House honeymoon voters may ending." In Senate race, Lt. Gov. Lee Fisher holds 24 - 21 percent lead Secretary State Jennifer Brunner race Democratic nomination, 51 percent undecided. Former U.S. Rep. Rob Portman holds 33 - 10 percent lead car dealer Tom Ganley Republican side, 55 percent undecided. In general election trial heats, Brunner would defeat Ganley 35 - 31 percent get 35 percent Portman's 34 percent. Fisher leads Ganley 36 - 30 percent Portman 37 - 33 percent. From June 26 - July 1, Quinnipiac University surveyed 1,259 Ohio voters, margin error +/- 2.8 percentage points. The survey includes 483 Democrats margin error +/- 4.5 percentage points 445 Republicans margin error +/-4.7 percentage points. The Quinnipiac University Poll, directed Douglas Schwartz, Ph.D., conducts public opinion surveys Florida, Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Ohio nation public service research. Dear Secretary Clinton, I hope elbow healing quickly. I mentioned work maritime developments region Persian Gulf East China Sea Sea Japan. Below key findings report, main takeaway political impact Chinese military modernization may greater narrow technical analysis China's capabilities would suggest, range reasons, technical political, prospects regional cooperation limited, pathways conflict numerous increasing. All best, Jackie Key findings workshop include: • Chinese naval modernization proceeded rates higher forecast 10 years ago created capability complicate operation US carrier battle groups within 1,000 kilometers Chinese coastline. • The Indian Ocean may coming decades operating area SSBNs countries limited experience sustained SSBN patrols, including India, China, possibly Pakistan. • Chinese maritime relations countries along littoral area continued develop, new friendly relationship emerging Sri Lanka, complement existing relations Myanmar Pakistan. This may lead new form "blue-brown water" naval operations, Chinese naval forces operate far Chinese bases, close coasts client states. The workshop tended conclusion trends region make maritime cooperation easy. These trends include: Japanese concern Chinese dominance waters within 1,000 miles Chinese territory immediate consequences Japan's maritime autonomy. • Indian suspicion Chinese naval developments Hainan Island, Chinese development port infrastructure Pakistan Myanmar, possibility Chinese ballistic missile submarines operating close India. • Indian interest SSBNs, plus Chinese SSBN ports Hainan even, possibly, Pakistani SSBNs, creates possibility multiple SSBN patrols Indian Ocean, along potential naval nuclear accidents sea. • Asymmetries levels operational competence, technology, submarines maritime aviation, which, example, make functional multi-national naval cooperation harder states afraid revealing technologies weaknesses. • The major role land-based maritime warfare strike complexes region, means war sea always carries risk escalation strikes ground targets homeland areas. The report also offers two scenarios United States may consider engaging militarily region. The first scenario, concerns clash Japan China waters claimed both, compels us consider: • The circumstances Chinese may seek demonstrate new maritime capabilities must taken seriously respected, • What United States would lose support Japanese, faced world Japan became either subordinate power China nuclear armed state, capable pursuing national interest independent United States. The second scenario concerns American naval blockade Iran tested nuclear weapon, potentially giving rise interaction United States China far operating bases close territory client China, "blue-brown water" clash. In scenario, China using navy show presence, force United States ask whether wants go war China political conflict less black white. Thinking options would left United States circumstances underscores Chinese naval forces may political impact 2025 narrow assessment military capabilities would suggest.
