"He'd say, 'Hey — fucking muscleheads couldn't find lunch without help. You got work together guys.'" Even new role America's leading evangelist counterinsurgency, McChrystal retains deep-seated instincts terrorist hunter. To put pressure Taliban, upped number Special Forces units Afghanistan four 19. "You better hitting four five targets tonight," McChrystal tell Navy Seal sees hallway headquarters. Then he'll add, "I'm going scold morning it, though." In fact, general frequently finds apologizing disastrous consequences counterinsurgency. In first four months year, NATO forces killed 90 civilians, 76 percent period 2009 — record created tremendous resentment among population COIN theory intent winning over. In February, Special Forces night raid ended deaths two pregnant Afghan women allegations cover-up, April, protests erupted Kandahar U.S. forces accidentally shot bus, killing five Afghans. "We've shot amazing number people," McChrystal recently conceded. Despite tragedies miscues, McChrystal issued strictest directives avoid civilian casualties U.S. military ever encountered war zone. It's "insurgent math," calls — every innocent person kill, create 10 new enemies. He ordered convoys curtail reckless driving, put restrictions use air power severely limited night raids. He regularly apologizes Hamid Karzai civilians killed, berates commanders responsible civilian deaths. "For while," says one U.S. official, "the dangerous place Afghanistan front McChrystal 'civ cas' incident." The ISAF command even discussed ways make killing something win award for: There's talk creating new medal "courageous restraint," buzzword that's unlikely gain much traction gung-ho culture U.S. military. But however strategic may be, McChrystal's new marching orders caused intense backlash among troops. Being told hold fire, soldiers complain, puts greater danger. "Bottom line?" says former Special Forces operator spent years Iraq Afghanistan. "I would love kick McChrystal nuts. His rules engagement put soldiers' lives even greater danger. Every real soldier tell thing." In March, McChrystal traveled Combat Outpost JFM — small encampment outskirts Kandahar — confront accusations troops directly. It typically bold move general. Only two days earlier, received e-mail Israel Arroyo, 25-year-old staff sergeant asked McChrystal go mission unit. "I writing said don't care troops made harder defend ourselves," Arroyo wrote. Within hours, McChrystal responded personally: "I'm saddened accusation I don't care soldiers, something I suspect soldier takes personally professionally — least I do. But I know perceptions depend upon perspective time, I respect every soldier's view own." Then showed Arroyo's outpost went foot patrol troops — bullshit photo-op stroll market, real live operation dangerous war zone. Six weeks later, McChrystal returned Paris, general received another e-mail Arroyo. A 23-year- old corporal named Michael Ingram — one soldiers McChrystal gone patrol — killed IED day earlier. It third man 25-member platoon lost year, Arroyo writing see general would attend Ingram's memorial service. "He started look you," Arroyo wrote. McChrystal said would try make pay respects soon possible. The night general scheduled visit Sgt. Arroyo's platoon memorial, I arrive Combat Outpost JFM speak soldiers gone patrol with. JFM small encampment, ringed high blast walls guard towers. Almost soldiers repeated combat tours Iraq Afghanistan, seen worst fighting wars. But especially angered Ingram's death. His commanders repeatedly requested permission tear house Ingram killed, noting often used combat position Taliban. But due McChrystal's new restrictions avoid upsetting civilians, request denied. "These abandoned houses," fumes Staff Sgt. Kennith Hicks. "Nobody coming back live them." One soldier shows list new regulations platoon given. "Patrol areas reasonably certain defend lethal force," laminated card reads. For soldier traveled halfway around world fight, that's like telling cop patrol areas knows won't make arrests. "Does make fucking sense?" asks Pfc. Jared Pautsch. "We drop fucking bomb place. You sit ask yourself: What here?" The rules handed McChrystal intended — they've distorted passed chain command — knowing nothing lessen anger troops ground. "Fuck, I came heard McChrystal charge, I thought would get fucking gun on," says Hicks, served three tours combat. "I get COIN. I get that. McChrystal comes here, explains it, makes sense. But goes away bird, time directives get passed us Big Army, they're fucked — either somebody trying cover ass, don't understand themselves. But we're fucking losing thing." McChrystal team show next day. Underneath tent, general 45-minute discussion two dozen soldiers. The atmosphere tense. "I ask what's going world, I think it's important understand big picture well," McChrystal begins. "How's company doing? You guys feeling sorry yourselves? Anybody? Anybody feel like you're losing?" McChrystal says. "Sir, guys here, sir, think we're losing, sir," says Hicks. McChrystal nods. "Strength leading don't want lead," tells men. "You're leading example. That's do. Particularly it's really, really hard, hurts inside." Then spends 20 minutes talking counterinsurgency, diagramming concepts principles whiteboard. He makes COIN seem like common sense, he's careful bullshit men. "We knee-deep decisive year," tells them. The Taliban, insists, longer initiative — "but I don't think do, either." It's similar talk gave Paris, it's winning hearts minds among soldiers. "This philosophical part works think tanks," McChrystal tries joke. "But doesn't get reception infantry companies." During question-and-answer period, frustration boils over. The soldiers complain allowed use lethal force, watching insurgents detain freed lack evidence. They want able fight — like Iraq, like Afghanistan McChrystal. 'We aren't putting fear Taliban," one soldier says. "Winning hearts minds COIN coldblooded thing," McChrystal says, citing oft-repeated maxim can't kill way Afghanistan. "The Russians killed 1 million Afghans, didn't work." "I'm saying go kill everybody, sir," soldier persists. "You say we've stopped momentum insurgency. I don't believe that's true area. The pull back, restrain ourselves, stronger it's getting." "I agree you," McChrystal says. "In area, we've made progress, probably. You show strength here, use fire. What I'm telling is, fire costs you. What want do? You want wipe population resettle it?" A soldier complains rules, insurgent doesn't weapon immediately assumed civilian. "That's way game is," McChrystal says. "It's complex. I can't decide: It's shirts skins, we'll kill shirts." As discussion ends, McChrystal seems sense hasn't succeeded easing men's anger. He makes one last-ditch effort reach them, acknowledging death Cpl. Ingram. "There's way I make easier," tells them. "No way I pretend won't hurt. No way I tell feel that. . . . I tell you, you're great job. Don't let frustration get you." The session ends clapping, real resolution. McChrystal may sold President Obama counterinsurgency, many men aren't buying it. When comes Afghanistan, history McChrystal's side. The foreign invader success Genghis Khan — wasn't hampered things like human rights, economic development press scrutiny. The COIN doctrine, bizarrely, draws inspiration biggest Western military embarrassments recent memory: France's nasty war Algeria (lost 1962) American misadventure Vietnam (lost 1975). McChrystal, like advocates COIN, readily acknowledges counterinsurgency campaigns inherently messy, expensive easy lose. "Even Afghans confused Afghanistan," says. But even somehow manages succeed, years bloody fighting Afghan kids pose threat U.S. homeland, war little shut Al Qaeda, shifted operations Pakistan. Dispatching 150,000 troops build new schools, roads, mosques water-treatment facilities around Kandahar like trying stop drug war Mexico occupying Arkansas building Baptist churches Little Rock. "It's cynical, politically," says Marc Sageman, former CIA case officer extensive experience region. "Afghanistan vital interest — there's nothing us there." In mid-May, two weeks visiting troops Kandahar, McChrystal travels White House high-level visit Hamid Karzai. It triumphant moment general, one demonstrates much command — Kabul Washington. In East Room, packed journalists dignitaries, President Obama sings praises Karzai. The two leaders talk great relationship is, pain feel civilian casualties. They mention word "progress" 16 times hour. But mention victory. Still, • session represents forceful commitment Obama made McChrystal's strategy months. "There denying progress Afghan people made recent years — education, health care economic development," president says. "As I saw lights across Kabul I landed — lights would visible years earlier." It disconcerting observation Obama make. During worst years Iraq, Bush administration real progress point to, officials used offer exact evidence success. "It one first impressions," one GOP official said 2006, landing Baghdad height sectarian violence. "So many lights shining brightly." So language Iraq War Obama administration turned — talk progress, city lights, metrics like health care education. Rhetoric years ago would mocked. "They trying manipulate perceptions definition victory — victory even defined recognizable," says Celeste Ward, senior defense analyst RAND Corporation served political adviser U.S. commanders Iraq 2006. "That's game we're right now. What need, strategic purposes, create perception didn't get run off. The facts ground great, going become great near future." But facts ground, history proven, offer little deterrent military determined stay course. Even closest McChrystal know rising anti-war sentiment home doesn't begin reflect deeply fucked things Afghanistan. "If Americans pulled back started paying attention war, would become even less popular," senior adviser McChrystal says. Such realism, however, doesn't prevent advocates counterinsurgency dreaming big: Instead beginning withdraw troops next year, Obama promised, military hopes ramp counterinsurgency campaign even further. "There's possibility could ask another surge U.S. forces next summer see success here," senior military official Kabul tells me. Back Afghanistan, less month White House meeting Karzai talk "progress," McChrystal hit biggest blow vision counterinsurgency. Since last year, Pentagon planning launch major military operation summer Kandahar, country's second-largest city Taliban's original home base. It supposed decisive turning point war — primary reason troop surge McChrystal wrested Obama late last year. But June 10th, acknowledging military still needs lay groundwork, general announced postponing offensive fall. Rather one big battle, like Fallujah Ramadi, U.S. troops implement McChrystal calls "rising tide security." The Afghan police army enter Kandahar attempt seize control neighborhoods, U.S. pours $90 million aid city win civilian population. Even proponents counterinsurgency hard-pressed explain new plan. "This isn't classic operation," says U.S. military official. "It's going Black Hawk Down. There aren't going doors kicked in." Other U.S. officials insist doors going kicked in, it's going kinder, gentler offensive disaster Marja. "The Taliban jackboot city," says military official. "We remove them, way doesn't alienate population." When Vice President Biden briefed new plan Oval Office, insiders say shocked see much mirrored gradual plan counterterrorism advocated last fall. "This looks like CT-plus!" said, according U.S. officials familiar meeting. Whatever nature new plan, delay underscores fundamental flaws counterinsurgency. After nine years war, Taliban simply remains strongly entrenched U.S. military openly attack. The people COIN seeks win — Afghan people — want us there. Our supposed ally, President Karzai, used influence delay offensive, massive influx aid championed McChrystal likely make things worse. "Throwing money problem exacerbates problem," says Andrew Wilder, expert Tufts University studied effect aid southern Afghanistan. "A tsunami cash fuels corruption, delegitimizes government creates environment we're picking winners losers" — process fuels resentment hostility among civilian population. So far, counterinsurgency succeeded creating never-ending demand primary product supplied military: perpetual war. There reason President Obama studiously avoids using word "victory" talks Afghanistan. Winning, would seem, really possible. Not even Stanley McChrystal charge. The Australian - 19 Jun 10 Embracing everyone US India Greg Sheridan, Foreign editor GEORGE Yeo, Singapore's Foreign Minister, one dazzlingly clever people could meet Southeast Asia. Singapore society notoriously produces hardheads strategic outlook. But Yeo combines Singapore's characteristic hard-headedness depth historical understanding context, well lively human sympathy diversity region surrounds him, I, event, find almost unique. I remember interviewing height East Asian economic crisis 1997 asking whether crisis shattered idea Asia growing centre global economy, numerous foolishly triumphalist Western commentators suggesting. "No doesn't," Yeo told me. "At might put back forecasts five 10 years." It moved graph little right, didn't change trends. On that, Yeo absolutely right. But also Yeo's ability apply insights history real problems Asia today make formidable. This week, Yeo spent days Australia I caught one slightly mesmerising historical tour de force conversations specialises. It secret Singapore serious reservations Kevin Rudd's proposal establish Asia-Pacific Community. The Prime Minister wanted US, India Russia included regional body could deal strategic issues well trade economics. Singapore's hesitation Rudd proposal came thought Association Southeast Asian Nations, key member, could sidelined. I asked Yeo whether region clear wanted organisations accomplish. "We still need lot discussion," said. "The vision going change dramatically, emergence China India global stage. The configuration evolving much faster us would preferred. But that's reality we've got work with. We need regional architecture able accommodate stresses. The single important relationship US China. Increasingly, relationship India China becoming important. I think eventually triangular relationship decide big issues war peace Asia century - triangle consisting US, China India." Yeo saw Rudd Foreign Minister Stephen Smith Canberra describes Canberra Singapore harmony evolution regional organisations. This saw played out: "When Prime Minister Rudd proposed APC, Dick Woolcott (Rudd's envoy) went round region. He visit countries. He made quite plain big countries ASEAN need involved. We talked among quite soon conclusion reached ASEAN going sidelined. So immediate blowback region. "To PM Rudd's credit quickly clarified this, ASEAN central conception APC vision beginning. I said, 'All us region relieved hear that'. "Separately (former Japanese) prime minister (Yukio) Hatoyama articulating view East Asian region apparently centred China, Japan Korea. It created, would expect, natural reaction Southeast Asia. That got us thinking region. How keep Russia US region way that's comfortable. For long time we've thinking China, recently India." Yeo pointed earlier regional organisations also evolved slowly, particular East Asia Summit, includes Australia New Zealand, well ASEAN, China, Japan, South Korea India. He said: "It took us long time create EAS structure. Some preferred based ASEAN plus three (China, Japan, Korea), harking back (former Malaysian prime minister) Mahathir (Mohamad)'s East Asian caucus. "Others felt that's limiting. If it's ASEAN plus three, may little lop-sided economic weight plus three. So thought India one side, Australia New Zealand south, there's certain natural equipoise. "Then took many discussions. The Russians wanted join EAS felt rushed. Russia important country. There unhappiness Russians accommodate EAS time. (Former US) President (George W.) Bush want join EAS worried EAS might exclude US region. We told American friends could purely Asian thing Australia New Zealand it. In case, countries like Singapore would never want EAS exclusive. What would threaten us world developed blocs." So end today? "When I met PM Rudd I thanked helping catalyse thinking ASEAN. So two possibilities, either EAS expanded Russia US separate ASEAN plus eight (including US Russia) configuration. In fact I interesting discussion Prime Minister Rudd. I think end he's happy let ASEAN members decide doesn't want interfere regional discussion." So describe Yeo outlines either win loss Rudd. Whatever evolves, nobody going call Asia-Pacific Community one going imagine Rudd founder, everyone accepts Bob Hawke founded APEC 1989. On hand, seem though it's much likely finally regional organisation embracing everyone US India, able discuss security. That pretty much Rudd's policy aim and, Yeo constructively puts it, Rudd influenced ASEAN thinking. Friends Rudd describe embodiment vision fulfilment initiative. His enemies say APC came nothing failure Australian diplomacy. Certainly Yeo casts constructive light. There space give smallest sampling Yeo's prodigiously rich insights issues. On US, said: "Both Australia Singapore feel bones US remain great power many decades. It vast country always throwing new ideas, always boil. It sunny disposition. We Singapore Australia feel bones one way another get current difficulties." On China, I asked whether political development keeping pace growth power, financial military, could manage new power way beneficial everybody. Yeo stressed sure Beijing's preoccupations internal, said: "China No 1 trading partner Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, India already No 2 New Zealand, countries (in Asia) graph points direction." (The historical process) high drama China. It historically large rural peasantry Maoism developed different ideology Bolshevism. China 20 per cent urban. It's 40 per cent urban go 80 per cent 90 per cent. The urbanisation Europe languid comparison, look Dickens Victor Hugo. Look huge reaction Europe urbanisation industrialisation. In China it's compressed. If succeed greatest nation Earth. The Chinese know learn new tricks. The skills brought power won't keep power." He recalled early China's economic modernisation program fascinated Singapore, mostly Chinese nation, ran society orderly effective manner, combining rapid economic growth social order respect tradition. Then interest seemed wane. But Chinese delegations back large numbers, fascinated particularly Singapore manages politics big booming city. Mainland Chinese even sitting politicians' electoral clinics Singapore, observing real problems recognised, integrated system dealt with. I asked Yeo whether thought Japan could sustain stabilising role played Asia past 60 years. He replied: "Their politics mess. Partly fit pieces together closely, reconfiguring pieces is- difficult. A lot Japanese politics fitting pieces together pulling apart. "The DP1 came power determined pull pieces apart, Liberal Democratic Party big business bureacracy. Never write Japan off. It takes long time change change fury intensity surprises everyone." Japan gone profound periods change past - Meiji Restoration 19th century, decided become modern nation; pervasive change World War II, decided embrace democracy role key US ally region. The fact grappling change reason think cannot emerge successful model. Yeo old, old friend Australia, sense long-term champion Australia's involvement Southeast Asia. He minister Singapore government 20 years. He embodies great deal institutional memory strategic continuity, within Singapore within broader councils region. It's pity doesn't visit us bit often.

May 6, 2010, 6:11 amIt's Not About Greece AnymoreBy PETER BOONE AND SIMON JOHNSONLouisa Gouliamaki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images Protesters waved flags Acropolis archaeological site behind banners English Greek hung front Parthenon temple Athens.Peter Boone chairman charity Effective Intervention research associate Center Economic Performance London School Economics. He also principal Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, former chief economist International Monetary Fund, co-author "13 Bankers."The Greek "rescue" package announced last weekend dramatic, unprecedented far enough stabilize euro zone.The Greek government European Union leadership, prodded International Monetary Fund, finally becoming realistic dire economic situation Greece. They abandoned previous rounds optimistic forecasts admitted profoundly worse situation. This new program calls "fiscal adjustments" — cuts fiscal deficit, mostly spending cuts — totaling 11 percent gross domestic product 2010, 4.3 percent 2011, 2 percent 2012 2013. The total debt-to-G.D.P. ratio peaks 149 percent 2012-13 starting gentle glide path back sanity.This new program honest enough show unlikely succeed.Daniel Gros, eminent economist euro zone issues based Brussels, argued 1 percent G.D.P. decline Greek government spending, total demand country falls 2.5 percent G.D.P. If government reduces spending 15 percent G.D.P. — initial shock demand could well 30 percent G.D.P.Obviously simple rule work large numbers, illustrates Greece likely experience sharp recession — substantial uncertainty around bad economy get. The program announced last weekend assumes Greek G.D.P. falls 4 percent year, another 2.6 percent 2011, recovering positive growth 2012 beyond.Such figures seem extremely optimistic, particularly face civil unrest sweeping Greece deep hostility expressed toward Greece northern European policy circles.The pattern growth critical because, program, Greece needs grow debt problem soon. Greece's debt-to-G.D.P. ratio debilitating 145 percent end 2011.Now consider putting realistic growth figures I.M.F. forecast Greece's economy — e.g., G.D.P. declining 12 percent 2011, debt-to-G.D.P. ratio may reach 155 percent. At levels, 5 percent real interest rate growth, country needs primary surplus 8 percent G.D.P. keep debt-to- G.D.P. ratio stable. It nowhere near level. The I.M.F. program Greece running primary budget deficit around 1 percent G.D.P. year, assumes path Greek growth regarded "upside scenario."The politics implied budget surpluses remains brutal. Since Greek debt held abroad, roughly 80 percent budget savings Greek government makes go straight Germans, French foreign debt holders (mostly banks). If growth turns poorly, Greeks prepared ever-tougher austerity pay Germans? Even everything goes well, Greek citizens seem unlikely welcome version "new normal." Last week European leadership panicked — late day — realized euro zone risk meltdown. If euro zone proves unwilling protect member like Greece default, bond investors run Portugal Spain also — doubt this, study carefully interlocking debt picture published recently The New York Times. Higher yields government debt would caused concerns potential bank runs nations, spread nations Europe.When "run," clear stops. In hazy distance, Belgium, France, Austria many others potentially risk. Even Germans cannot afford bail nations.Slapped face ugly scenario, Europeans decided throw everything I.M.F. bailing Greece. The program announced small chance preventing eventual Greek bankruptcy, may still slow avert dangerous spiral downward — enormous collateral damage — rest Europe.The I.M.F. floated fashion alternative scenario debt restructuring, rejected European Union Greek authorities. This surprise; leading European policy makers completely unprepared broader problems would follow Greek "restructuring," markets would immediately mark debt (i.e., increase yields) Portugal, Spain, Ireland even Italy.The fear panic face would unparalleled modern times: When Greeks pay 50 percent face value debt, investors expect Portuguese Spanish? It becomes arbitrary, including countries dragged down.Someone decide defended cost, European structures completely unsuited kind tough decision-making pressurein extreme downside scenario, Germany obvious safe haven within euro zone, government bond yields would collapse governments face sharply rising yields. The euro zone would likely hold together.There still narrow escape path, without immediate debt default chaos would produce:- Talk euro — moving toward parity American dollar would help lift growth across euroz one.- As euro falls, bond yields rise euro zone periphery. This create episodes panic. Enough short-term financing must place support rollover government debt.. Once euro fallen great deal, announce European Central Bank support euro levels (i.e., prevent appreciation, G-20 tacit agreement), also support peripheral euro zone nations viewed solvent buying bonds whenever markets chaotic.• At stage, before, euro zone leadership needs push weaker governments restructure. That include Greece perhaps also Portugal. Hopefully, scenario Spain muddle through.• European banks recapitalized necessary management replaced. This massive failure euro groupthink — including notably political level — question bank executives behaved responsibly long replaced en masse.To extent possible, ensuing losses shared bank creditors. But careful wish for. The bankers powerful reason; built vital yet fragile structures heart economies. Dismantle care.

In general, senators give speeches floor, colleagues aren't around, two three might present aren't listening. They're joking aides, e-mailing Twitter ideas press secretaries, getting first look speech they're give eight unmanned cameras provide live feed C-SPAN2. The presiding officer Senate—freshmen majority party take rotating, hour-long shifts intended introduce ways institution—sits chair dais, scanning BlackBerry reading Times article Senate. Michael Bennet, freshman Democrat Colorado, said, "Sit watch us seven days—just watch floor. You know you'll see happening? Nothing. When I'm chair, I sit thinking, I wonder they're China right now?" Between speeches, quorum calls, time killers Senate clerk calls roll rate one name every minutes. The people pay attention speech Senate stenographers. Like many aspects senatorial procedure, Rule XXVI, Paragraph 5 relic days senators hover around desks know happening floor main afternoon debate. (The desks, built long ago 1819, mahogany, lids lift up, like old schoolhouse; desks Majority Minority Leader still equipped brass spittoons.) In press lounge, McCaskill said, light sarcasm, "Somebody told rule make sure people pay attention what's happening floor debate distracted committee work. Clearly, it's old rule." The Republicans turned old rule new means obstruction. There would hearings afternoon; general admiral would come back another day. Like investment bankers Wall Street, senators days direct much creative energy toward manipulation arcane rules loopholes, scoring short-term successes magnifying institution's broader dysfunction. Around five o'clock, chamber began fill, reconciliation bill came vote; twenty-three amendments pending, Republicans, perhaps many come. Ordinarily, debate voting amendment might take two legislative days, rules reconciliation bill senators dispatch amendments one another, hot-dog-eating contest, minute debate side. The goal finish bill end evening, senators wouldn't miss day spring recess—apparently, thing worse government takeover health-care system. The usual longueurs Senate, forty minutes tick away antique clock rear double doors without word's spoken, yield frenzy. Harry Reid, Majority Leader, Nevada, predicted process, known Vote-O-Rama, would go past two morning, warned senators stay close chamber. Max Baucus, Montana, manager bill Democrats, rose said, "This first time recent memory reconciliation bill amendments one side only. These clearly amendments designed kill reconciliation and, therefore, kill health-care reform. So I much hope amendments defeated." Tall, gaunt Judd Gregg, New Hampshire, bill's Republican manager, took floor. "The position side aisle is: amendments allowed, even good," said. Indignation rouged cheeks, voice rose half octave. "Obviously, presume Republican Party inconvenience. The democratic process inconvenience. It also appears, considering opposition America, American people inconvenience." The Senate chamber laid four concentric semicircles, adjacent desks almost touching crowded Democratic side, desks much smaller Republican minority spaced loosely apart. The design meant emphasize senators' unity. But Baucus Gregg avoided eye contact across six feet aisle divides chamber two constantly warring factions. Senators required, custom, speak one another third person, directing anger sarcasm whichever poor freshman happens presiding officer moment. Rule XIX, Paragraphs 2 3—one original rules drawn Thomas Jefferson's "Manual Parliamentary Practice"—bars senators imputing unworthy conduct motives another senator, insulting senator's state. But rule finger-wagging, Baucus wagged Gregg shouting Al Franken, Minnesota, started shift presiding officer's chair: "Mr. President, make mistake, intent every single one amendments offered side aisle kill health-care reform. . . . A senator side aisle stood said hopefully President's Waterloo. They want kill health-care reform!" The voice Stuart Smalley filled chamber: "The time senator expired." For next nine hours, chamber became stage theatrical whose ending, like almost everything happens Senate floor, known advance all. The Republican goal Vote-O-Rama embarrass Democrats appearing suggest useful changes; Democratic goal prevent change bill, wouldn't return House, might voted down. Several Republican amendments designed make Democrats look hypocritical, forcing vote policies Party typically supports. One amendment, example, declared health-care bill could linked tax hike individuals making less two hundred thousand dollars year. Other amendments nakedly partisan, outlandish. David Vitter, Louisiana Republican, proposed amendment repealed entire law. Senator Tom Coburn, Republican obstetrician Oklahoma, introduced amendment insure veterans diagnosed mental illness would denied right firearms, another prevent "convicted child molesters, rapists, sex offenders" buying erectile-dysfunction drugs taxpayer funds. Coburn got minute allotted explain Viagra amendment without cracking smile. "This game amendment," insisted. "It actually saves money." So many senators snickered presiding officer banged gavel order. "The amendment offered senator Oklahoma makes mockery Senate," Baucus declared. "It crass political stunt aimed making thirty-second commercials, public policy." Baucus asked yeas nays, clerk called roll ragged pace. "Mr. Coburn, Mr. Cochran, Ms. Collins." Thirty-five-second pause. "Mr. Conrad, Mr. Corker." Ten seconds. "Mr. Cornyn." Senators pay attention sound name; cast votes they're inclined—wandering late, shuffling chamber's gentle blue-carpeted steps swarm colleagues milling well, clerks sit table, holding finger down. At one point, John McCain— one hundred senators struggling stay office—spent half minute waving stiff-armed, trying catch eye clerk could cast vote. In end, two Democrats—Evan Bayh, Indiana, Ben Nelson, Nebraska—joined Republicans opposing Viagra sex offenders. The amendment defeated. The carpeting chamber absorbs voices, long night one rose muffled drone Charles Schumer, said Gregg, "Get work! Stop screwing around health care!" Sporadically, sharp cackle emanated Al Franken, wandered chamber, looking Republicans could charm laughing. Observed press gallery, senators confined space began resemble zoo animals—Levin shambling brown bear, John Thune loping gazelle, Jim Bunning maddened grizzly. Each one displayed limited set behaviors: conversations, John Kerry planted inches away, loomed, clamped hands colleague's shoulders. Joe Lieberman patted everyone back. It became clear senators loners (Russ Feingold, Daniel Akaka) social (Blanche Lincoln, Lindsey Graham); senators important (Dick Durbin, Jon Kyl) ignored (Bayh, Bunning). Past midnight, Durbin slumped desk, one hand face, yawning painfully. Susan Collins going mail. Twenty-three amendments voted down, Republicans proposing fresh batch. "Can get order?" Bunning growled, introduced proposal let senior citizens opt parts Medicare. It amendment Republicans joined Democrats defeat. Harry Reid controls Senate's schedule, Mitch McConnell, Kentucky, Minority Leader, object. Since nearly everything Senate depends unanimous consent, main business place continuous negotiation two supremely unsentimental men. That night, played game chicken: McConnell, unsmiling, eyes riveted ahead, held prospect dozens amendments; Reid, former boxer, hunched mumbling, playing rope-a-dope, vowing fend amendments night. The two leaders left chamber confer privately proceed. Inside, atmosphere slumber party set in. Debbie Stabenow, Michigan, hand across heart, sang sentimental duet Robert Menendez, New Jersey. Exhaustion momentarily eased partisan divide. Claire McCaskill sat beside Tom Coburn, held erect finger face, casting Viagra vote, let go limp. Coburn could heard joke, "The longest lasted thirty seconds." At two-forty-five morning, Reid suddenly declared Senate adjourned. The Senate parliamentarian found two small violations reconciliation rules, meaning morning, despite Democrats' efforts, bill would go back House another vote. At bang gavel, senators fled. In parking lot, Capitol's northeast side, McCaskill climbed S.U.V. Levin, cramped sedan, chauffeured empty streets. On marble ledge near exit, Arlen Specter sat alone, ghost brown suit, staring straight ahead, waiting someone take away. The Senate reconvened 9:45 A.M. Around two afternoon, members gathered final vote, Democrats giddy. Tom Harkin, Iowa, Christopher Dodd, Connecticut, even exchanged hug. "Everyone's tired," Reid declared final vote. "This legislative fight one record books." He fatigued initially voted wrong way. Lindsey Graham came late, delaying tally ten minutes. "Way go, Lindsey, way stretch out," Sam Brownback told him. A Republicans lingered took moment, like players losing team end World Series. After year work, health-care reform passed, 56-43, moment chamber's Tweeting pygmies become legislative giants. The Senate often referred "the world's greatest deliberative body." Jeff Merkley, freshman Democrat Oregon, said, "That phrase I wince time I hear it, amount real deliberation, terms exchange ideas, limited." Merkley could remember witnessing one moment floor debate Republican Democrat. "The memory I took was: 'Wow, that's unusual—there's conversation occurring they're making point counterpoint challenging other.' And yet nobody else chamber." Tom Udall, freshman Democrat New Mexico, could recall seeing senator change another senator's mind. "You would really need good hour two extensive exchange among folks really know issue," said. Instead, senator typically gives "a prepared speech that's already vetted staff. Then another guy gets gives speech completely different subject." From time time, senators party carry colloquy—"I would interested distinguished senator Iowa's view side's Medicare Advantage plan"—that scripted advance aides. While senators Washington, days scheduled fifteen-minute intervals: staff meetings, interviews, visits lobbyists home-state groups, caucus lunches, committee hearings, briefing books, floor votes, fund-raisers. Each senator sits three four committees even subcommittees, meet morning hours, helps explain committee tables often nearly empty, senators drifting hearing barely sustain coherent line questioning. All activity crammed three-day week, it's unwritten rule modern Senate votes almost never scheduled Mondays Fridays, allows senators spend four days away capital. Senators now, unlike several decades ago, often keep families home states, return weekends, even it's Alaska Idaho—a concession endless fund-raising, populist anti-Washington mood recent years. (When Newt Gingrich became Speaker House, 1995, told new Republican members move families capital.) The upper chamber Congress constitutional compromise popular sovereignty state sovereignty. The Senate designed, part separation powers, check impulses House popular will. For Federalists, also aristocratic purpose: collect knowledge experience, guard levelling spirit might overtake majority. When Alexis de Tocqueville visited Senate, 1832, deeply impressed quality members: "They represent lofty thoughts [of nation] generous instincts animating it, petty passions." But also recognized "a minority nation dominating Senate could completely paralyze majority represented house, contrary spirit constitutional government." As long Senate continued composed America's talented statesmen, Tocqueville implied, would restrain anti-democratic potential. Robert A. Caro, "Master Senate," third volume life Lyndon Johnson, argues Civil War • Senate captured wealthy sectional interests, ending high-minded age Daniel Webster, Henry Clay, John C. Calhoun engaged brilliant debate. Aside spasms legislation start Presidencies Woodrow Wilson Franklin Roosevelt, Caro writes, Senate remained controlled alliance Southern racists Republican corporate shills, "the dam waves social reform dashed vain— chief obstructive force federal government." By fifties, Senate become far conservative public. And conservative: William S. White, 1956 book "Citadel," called Senate "to peculiar degree, Southern Institution . . . growing heart ostensibly national assembly" "the place country South lose war." By mid-century, become journalistic cliché call Senate broken. Otto Preminger's 1962 film "Advise Consent," based novel Allen Drury, Senate period, presents Democrats Republicans equally amoral, calculating, power-hungry. But institution, depicted Preminger, still works, way: though deals stink, get cut. The senators know colleagues rules; back-stab one another lunchroom, drink cocktails play cards Saturday nights. There lobbyists, fund-raisers, media, constituents—only senators' intricate relations one another. The Senate world. In memoir, Johnson's longtime aide Harry McPherson recalls learning Senate's "famous 'club' atmosphere based members' mutual acceptance responsibility concentration tasks hand. . . . They thrust hard one another debate serious matters," but, writes, "understanding accommodation ordinary course Senate day essential sanity." Johnson, powerful Majority Leader history, bent Senate forced become efficient. He saw colleagues either "whales"—the heavyweight chairmen negotiated legislation—or "minnows," followers went along brokered deals. And when, 1958, formidable new class liberal Democrats entered Senate—including Edmund Muskie, Eugene McCarthy, Philip Hart—the legislative machinery began produce reform. Michael Janeway, author "The Fall House Roosevelt," worked summer staff member 1958 1962. "They used talk other—that's vivid recollection," said. "If Wayne Morse talked constitutional law floor, Southerners would come hear him. The Hubert Humphrey farm policy. My strongest impression deliberative body, drawing out—sometimes pedantically." Senators ran office order work foreign policy, social welfare, urbanization win credibility whales. "But wanted something mechanism could it," Janeway said. In sixties seventies, Southern-conservative control broken coalition left-of-center Democrats moderate Republicans. Donald Ritchie, Senate historian, started working 1976, described Senate decades "a bipartisan liberal institution." The Civil Rights Act 1964 written largely office Republican Minority Leader, Everett Dirksen. Every major initiative—voting rights, open housing, environmental law, campaign reform—enjoyed bipartisan support. In rare event filibuster, motion end debate often filed jointly leaders parties. When Medicare—that government takeover health care elderly—was passed, 1965, won 70-24. The Senate's momentum nurtured superb talent: William Fulbright, Everett Dirksen, Henry Jackson, Frank Church, Howard Baker. In 1969, George McGovern chaired select committee hunger actually held bipartisan "field hearings" poor regions, calling witnesses migrant labor camps, then, Bob Dole's indispensable support, greatly expanded food-stamp program. The intensity senatorial purpose years must strike today's legislators profoundly humbling. After Joe Biden came Senate, 1973, Hubert Humphrey took aside said, "You pick issue becomes yours. That's attract colleagues follow you, Joe. That's demonstrate bona fides. Don't gadfly." Humphrey's career advice: "You become Mr. Housing. Housing future." The Senate's modern decline began 1978, election new wave anti-government conservatives, accelerated Republicans became majority 1981. "The Quayle generation came in, number people like Dan—same generation, hair style, beliefs," Gary Hart, Colorado Democrat, recalled. "They harder-line. They weren't get along Democrats. But look accommodationist compared Republicans Senate today." Church, McGovern, Javits, Birch Bayh gone. Ira Shapiro, former aide, writing book Senate sixties seventies, said, "It huge loss experienced, accomplished senators replaced neophytes. All sudden, 1981, half Senate less six years." He added, "The shattering great Senate long-term effects keep showing up. It gets worse time, never gets restored. There phrase I heard Helms younger ones: 'Others didn't want make waves; I wanted drain swamp.'" After C-SPAN went air, 1979, cozy atmosphere encouraged deliberation back-room deals began yield transparency and, it, posturing. "So Damn Much Money," recent book Washington Post reporter Robert G. Kaiser, traces spectacular rise Washington lobbying period. Liberal Republicans began disappear, Southern Democrats died replaced conservative Republicans. Bipartisan coalitions wings Senate vanished. The institutionalist gave way free agent, controlled fund-raising apparatus media presence, whose electoral base patchwork single-issue groups. Members parties—Howard Metzenbaum, Ohio Democrat; Jesse Helms, North Carolina Republican—took regularly using Senate's rules tie business narrowly ideological reasons. The number filibusters shot eighties continued rise following decades, parties kept alternating control Senate escalating procedural arms race, routinely blocking confirmation executive judicial appointees. Democrats filibustered Republican nominees bench; Republicans threatened ban filibuster cases—the so- called "nuclear option." Older members perturbed when, 2004, Republican Majority Leader, Bill Frist, went South Dakota campaign Democratic Minority Leader, Tom Daschle (who went lose). A years earlier, action would unthinkable. The weakened institution could longer withstand pressures outside walls; money cameras rushed in, independent minds fell line partisans. Rough parity two parties meant every election potential make break majority, crushing incentive cooperate across aisle. The Senate, longer fount ideas, became backwater U.S. government. During Clinton years, main action White House Gingrich House Representatives; Bush years, Republican Senate majority abdicated oversight role could placed vital check executive power. He went on, "When get good people come in, quickly get ground dynamic culture parties. And get there, look takes stay there." When spend days Senate, it's easy forget everything else. The House Representatives seems miles away (it's corridor across rotunda), White House another country, actual foreign countries unimaginable. The place remains insular, labyrinthine, opaque—even physically. Senators commute thirty seconds offices chamber electric subway cars run along tunnel Constitution Avenue. Many signs misleading obsolete (the gilded lettering visitors' gallery says "Men's Gallery"), Capitol filled secret passageways spare rooms, called hideaways, doled according seniority, senators read, drink, doze, wait buzzer announcing imminent vote. The pervasive authority institution Constitution Bible but, rather, impenetrable sixteen-hundred-page tome, Floyd M. Riddick, called "Senate Procedure: Precedents Practices," late Robert Byrd, West Virginia, known read entirety. The procedures abstruse parliamentarian must sit presiding officer and, essentially, tell say. After half century, picture given Preminger's "Advise Consent" still faintly visible. Which exactly problem: it's self-governing body depends reasonableness members function. Sarah Binder, congressional scholar George Washington University, said, "To chamber rules unanimous consent—it's nutty! Especially you've got Jim Bunning please." In 2006 2008, sixteen Democrats entered Senate, giving Party current majority fifty-nine forty-one (counting two independents). They include moderates, like Jon Tester, Montana, Mark Warner, Virginia; liberals, like Sherrod Brown, Ohio, Sheldon Whitehouse, Rhode Island; policy specialists, like Amy Klobuchar, Minnesota, Jeff Merkley; iconoclasts, like Claire McCaskill. Their interest legislating won admiration senior senators. "If stay, I think they'll terrific," Chris Dodd said. "My worry won't stay. Because it's productive." Earlier year, Senate's procedural absurdities became national news twice one month. On February 4th, Con gressDaily reported Richard Shelby, Alabama Republican, secretly blocking confirmation seventy Obama appointees dispute involving defense earmarks his•state. (His tactics exposed, Shelby—whose office maintains responsible fewer fifty holds—lifted three.) Later month, Bunning spent several days late night Senate floor, filibustering prevent benefits paid millions unemployed Americans. When Merkley tried reason him, Bunning responded, "Tough shit." (Eventually, Republicans persuaded Bunning stop.) These incidents elicited brief outcry, extent Senate's routine folly remains largely hidden. For example, Grassley Ron Wyden, Oregon, trying since 1997 end practice secret holds, without success. In 2007, Senate passed bill banning secret holds last longer six days. But get around ban two senators pass hold back forth—it's called "rolling holds"—and party leader facilitates game keeping names secret. Many Senate's antique rules precedents warped beyond recognition modern pressures partisanship. The hold, example, courtesy extended senators days horse travel, needed time get back Washington read bill question appointee casting vote. Sarah Binder, co- authored book filibuster, calls procedure historical accident: 1806, Senate got rid little-used rule allowed "previous question" called vote. Suddenly, inherent limit debate, eighteen-thirties senators begun taking advantage loophole, derailing proceedings getting talking voice, legs, bladder gave out. (The word "filibuster' comes vrijbuiter—old Dutch "looter.") In 1917, Woodrow Wilson, wartime legislative agenda blocked filibusters, forced Senate pass Rule XXII, allowed two-thirds majority bring floor debate end "cloture" vote. For decades, rule rarely used; 1919 1971, forty-nine cloture votes, fewer one per year. In seventies eighties, annual average rose dozen. (Frustration increase led Senate, 1975, lower threshold cloture sixty votes.) In nineties early aughts, average went twenty-five thirty year, parties escalated use filibuster found minority. After Republicans lost majority 2006, filibusters became everyday events: hundred twelve cloture votes 2007 2008, session Republicans target break filibuster record. The tally cloture votes reflects small fraction senatorial obstruction. Three hundred forty-five bills passed House prevented even coming debate Senate. "Why?" Steny Hoyer, outraged Democratic Majority Leader House, asked me. "Because business way facilitates noncontroversial things. Thankfully, House Representatives becoming Senate." Last week, six House Democrats expressed displeasure upper chamber staging sit-in sorts Senate floor. (The Democrats also practiced art blocking nominees Bush Administration.) There's often objection individual blocked: eight-month hold, Martha Johnson, nominated run General Services Administration, confirmed 96-0. On issue like health-care reform, objection substantive, Republicans ransacked Riddick's "Senate Procedure" every conceivable way delay debate vote. Judd Gregg even sent memo stalling tactics Republican colleagues. Tom Coburn demanded reading aloud entire seven-hundred-and-sixty-seven-page amendment proposed Bernie Sanders, Vermont socialist; Senate clerks, working half-hour shifts, three hours chore Sanders withdrew amendment frustration. Under McConnell, Republicans consistently consumed much Senate's calendar possible legislative maneuvering. The strategy extend deliberation Senate's agenda prevent it. Tom Harkin, first proposed reform filibuster 1995, called Republican colleagues "nihilists," want create chaos serves ideology. "If there's chaos, things tend toward simple solutions," Harkin said. "In chaos people don't listen reason." McConnell respond requests interview, often argued Republican strategy reflects views majority Americans. In March, told Times, "To extent they"—the Democrats— "want things think political center would helpful country, we'll helpful. To extent trying turn us Western European country, going helpful." Why moderates years experience power base back home—Richard Lugar, Indiana; Susan Collins, Maine; George Voinovich, Ohio—keep siding extreme members caucus? Alexander said McConnell listens well members, adding, "When back wall gallows hanging front you, tends unify. Operating forty members—it concentrates mind." Lindsey Graham described Times McConnell exhorted caucus disastrous 2008 election: "He said didn't stick together big things, wouldn't relevant." Last December, Republicans decided filibuster military-spending bill order delay looming vote health care close Christmas possible. Thad Cochran, Republican ranking member Appropriations Committee, promised Daniel Inouye, chairman, wouldn't join effort. But last minute Cochran, Senate since 1979 brings disproportionate amounts defense money Mississippi, told Reid leadership wouldn't allow vote Democrats end filibuster—even matter national security. (The Democrats able impose cloture, vote health care finally took place Christmas Eve.) Republican defections rare. In early 2009, Collins Olympia Snowe, also Maine, voted stimulus bill, along Arlen Specter (who promptly switched parties). Snowe also voted Finance Committee's health-care- reform bill last October, Republican so. But December, pivotal moment, voted version went full Senate. "I wasn't interested expanding program beyond Finance Committee version—it grew thousand pages," Snowe said. She wasn't included negotiations White House officials took place elegant conference room across Reid's suite offices, said Democrats "did accept proposals. As I said President, windup pitch." McConnell able exploit alienation. A friend Snowe cited another reason reversal: "She actually said never felt pressure felt health care, never pressure quite evident quite real troubling. Kyl McConnell saying things like 'You can't let us down, we're together. You're senior Republican member caucus, hang tough us. We expect you're going it.' " Reid doesn't use tough tactics; achieved position, spite public shortcomings, senator helped Democrats, always answered calls, got wanted masterly maneuvering. This made enormously popular within Democratic caucus, doesn't give leverage McConnell, let alone Lyndon Johnson. In current Senate, become normal handful senators, sometimes representing ten twenty per cent country's population, hold everything up. And status quo become sufficiently frustrating new senators considered radical option: mutiny. Tom Udall, sixty-two, older freshman senators. He crow's-feet Westerner spent time sun, slow, good-natured voice. His father, Stewart, Arizona congressman Interior Secretary Presidents Kennedy Johnson; uncle Mo legendary Arizona representative; cousin Mark freshman senator Colorado. Udall served five terms House winning Senate seat New Mexico, 2008. And yet air political Candide—he always earnest, capable disappointment cynicism. "I ran idea Senate graveyard good ideas," said. "Then inside—the thing strikes one senator hold whole show." In first year office, Udall decided something audacious: would try change Senate's rules. Customarily, rules continue session session, provision Rule XXII requires sixty-seven votes amend them, making extremely difficult. ("Rule XXII Catch-22," Ted Kennedy used joke.) Udall embraced different idea—the "constitutional option." Article I, Section 5 Constitution states "each House may determine Rules Proceedings" beginning new Congress. So, theory, senator could take floor next January propose debating rules scratch, including filibuster. New rules could passed simple majority. There's even precedent this: moves revisit rules invoking constitutional option made three times, recently 1975. Udall spent much past year trying build support idea. At request Udall others, Schumer, chairman Rules Committee, held series hearings filibuster, calling witnesses Sarah Binder, historian, Walter Mondale, Senate constitutional option invoked 1975. Dick Durbin, second-highest-ranking Democrat, organized working groups among newer members internal reforms, ending secret holds choosing committee chairs caucus vote rather seniority. (Lamar Alexander wryly suggested Schumer Durbin competing favor newer members, case Harry Reid loses seat fall run Majority Leader.) For Republican institutionalists, Alexander Gregg, push rules reform folly. "If want parliamentary form government, go House," Gregg, retire, scoffed. "Why even run Senate?" Udall's plan next January, said, would "gigantic mistake." "They'll get it," Alexander said Democrats' enthusiasm rules reform. "And they'll get quicker they're minority next January. Because they'll instantly see value slowing Senate consider whatever say." He added Senate "may getting done much American people want done." The President's ambitious agenda, all, upset lot voters, across political spectrum. None Republicans I spoke agreed contention Senate "broken." Alexander claimed Republicans exercising moderating, thoughtful influence legislation founders wanted Senate. "The Senate wasn't created efficient," argued. "It created inefficient." At one filibuster hearings, April, Alexander, sitting across table Udall, said that, times Democrats charge Republicans obstructing legislation, "we could say that's number times majority tried cut right debate, right offer amendments, essence Senate." Newcomers like Udall seem think Senate grown absurd extreme kind reform inevitable. Perhaps need time plumb depths institution's intransigence. According Sarah Binder, change rules extremely unlikely; Republicans would implacably opposed to, say, weakening filibuster, would Democrats, especially long-serving ones. "I would oppose that," Chris Dodd said, adding freshmen, "These people never minority." For older Democrats, put years, grown adept working rules, chair powerful committees, reform impulse could threat. (Among senior senators, sole enthusiast rules reform Tom Harkin.) One senator spoke Senate divided whales minnows but, rather, bulls calves. The older Democrats accustomed Senate's ways share frustrations newcomers; handful older moderate Republicans weak challenge newer radicals dominate caucus. Even freshmen Democrats somehow reform filibuster next January, Senate remain sclerotic, wasteful, unhappy body. The deepest source problems rules precedents but, rather, human beings, created culture Tocqueville's "lofty thoughts" "generous impulses" place. A days passing health-care reform, Senate struggled feet take second large task. Financial regulatory reform easiest piece major legislation Obama Presidency, likeliest win real bipartisan support. The financial crisis catastrophic millions Americans, 2008 bailout Wall Street become even hated Senate was. In April, lineup bankers Goldman Sachs appeared Senator Levin's subcommittee investigations, managed appear arrogant, callous, evasive reputations suggested. The public demanded action. Some Republicans genuine desire pass bill. If health-care reform war attrition, financial reform promising liaison. The affair began Republican, Bob Corker, Democrat, Mark Warner—both multimillionaires serving first term, considered centrists. Corker small, dapper former construction magnate became mayor Chattanooga; Warner tall, preppily dressed former telecommunications entrepreneur became governor Virginia. Chris Dodd, Banking Committee chairman, assigned work together section bill liquidation troubled firms—making sure would never another taxpayer bailout. They worked winter, Warner's office, Corker's office, dinner, sometimes without staff, members Senate past. They hosted series afternoon seminars, inviting guests Ben Bernanke, Alan Greenspan, Sheila Bair. Corker Warner sometimes said Democrat Republican still talking other. In January, Business Week called Senate's "Odd Couple." By February, finished work. Meanwhile, discussions entire bill Dodd Richard Shelby, top Republican committee, dragged on, repeatedly breaking down. Finally, February 10th, Dodd called Corker, who, though one committee's junior members, agreed chairman's Republican negotiating partner. When Corker informed McConnell Shelby, expressed surprise. "It odd place be," Corker recalled. "And yet night began meeting." The junior Republican savored rare experience creating, rather opposing, legislation. In response, Shelby's conservative staff tried undermine Corker, spreading rumors among Republicans lobbyists giving much away. (A Shelby aide said staff members simply informing Republicans Party's line financial reform.) On March 10th, Dodd concluded move bill floor. He called Corker said, "You've great partner." He ending talks month. "It's little stunning, I've got honest," Corker told reporters afterward. Someone close negotiations compared Corker Dickens's Miss Havisham, unable get rebuff, forever awaiting arrival groom, clocks stopped. Corker later said Dodd ended talks pressure White House Democrats. Dodd said Corker unable bring Republicans him. "Baloney," Corker said. "If Dodd reached agreement me, we'd've least twenty- five Republican votes." The bill Dodd brought Senate, year discussions Democrats Republicans alike, incorporated bipartisan plan Warner Corker prevent another bank bailout: setting fifty-billion-dollar fund, paid banks, insure orderly liquidation, establishing risk council detect warning signs another crisis. But mid-April Mitch McConnell—who met Wall Street executives New York, parroting talking points memo written Republican strategist Frank Luntz—called "partisan bill" "will guarantee perpetual taxpayer bailout Wall Street banks." McConnell presented letter, signed forty-one Republicans, suggesting would filibuster financial-reform bill. His remarks amounted repudiation Corker's work well Dodd's. The next day, April 15th, Corker pleaded colleagues, Tennessee twang, "Let's come floor let's act like adults. Let's tone rhetoric. Let's don't exaggerate pluses minuses. Let's Senate created do. . . . We supposed people took red-hot activities sometimes come body sat cooler heads resolved issues like adults. We that. As matter fact, I would say, cannot financial regulation, issue really doesn't real philosophical bearings . . ." Corker didn't allow thought ripen—he already gone farther almost Republican would dared. Dodd spoke later day completed Corker's speech: "I know friends side aisle faced difficult choice supporting party leadership participating complicated, difficult debate. I naïve. I know hard place be. But can't act like U.S. senators sake issue . . . even here?" He went on, "We work American public sick tired feeling like one looking interests, like political hacks lobbyists hold cards discussions. The minority seems intent proving right. . . . I long time. I know institution better that. I know friends mine side aisle care bill, want part debate, want part solution." In speech, Dodd joined partisan fight, accusing McConnell lying bill. Turning crimson-faced, chopped air hand shouted, "I ask myself, I go process last four five months, agreeing much offering, single political vote show it. . . . I say younger members, newer members coming along: careful!" Corker, heard Dodd speaking, returned chamber asked respond. "You I went long way," Corker told Dodd. "Then stopped. On March 10th ended. I understand that, look, losing Democrats committee." "And I gaining Republicans," Dodd replied. "You one, asked started. I never said I could speak anybody myself. And I leave table." Corker urged Dodd keep talking Republicans—their differences could sorted days. But McConnell's agenda. Instead, financial reform became slightly polite repeat health-care- reform brawl: Republicans threatened filibusters, Democrats threatened all-nighters, thousands lobbyists prowled Capitol, charging Wall Street clients billion dollars. On April 28th, I sitting ornate Reception Room Jim Manley, Reid's spokesman. On side wall, noise furniture scraping across tile floor. "Those cots set L.B.J. Room," Manley said. "Very little happens around without deadline." The cots persuaded Republicans allow bill move floor debate. A weeks later, May 20th, yet another filibuster defeated yet another cloture motion, financial reform finally came vote. It passed, 59-39. Only four Republicans joined majority. Corker wasn't among them. He even voted amendment, offered Republican colleague Jeff Sessions, Alabama, would scrapped Corker's work many months Warner. "The idea watching Bob Corker vote Sessions amendment!" Dodd said afterward, sitting red-curtained office, print Holbein's portrait Thomas More. "It's Senate, I guess." McConnell's strategy obstruction come close succeeding, Dodd said, knew "shrinking number" Republicans frustrated. The previous day, Dodd said Susan Collins, "God, I would loved ranking member this." Collins responded, "We could great time bill." Warner, said believed bipartisanship "the American people don't trust either political party enough give blank check," astonished Republicans voted financial reform. "There zero substantive reason couldn't eighty votes," said. I asked Bob Corker voted bill. Warner started talk consumer-protection title, said, "If want vote something, always find reasons." But Corker hadn't seemed want vote it. He spent months trying act like U.S. senator, alienating party party, day vote held floor better part thirty minutes, still reluctant let effort go. "I obviously disappointed," said. "I think I spent much time senator. . . policy regarding financial system. I think bill—even bill—has good things it. There question. And I appreciate thrust. But I think lot overreaching, I think enough time spent core issues." As senators cast votes, I noticed Robert Kaiser, author "So Damn Much Money," press gallery. I later asked if, passage two big reform bills three months, witnessing possible renewal Senate. "If engage public opinion way politicians understand, public opinion still blow away money interest groups," said. "But past decades reflex grown Senate that, things considered, it's better avoid take big issues. This kind thing drives Michael Bennet nutty: you've arrived United States Senate can't fuck-all destruction planet." After final vote financial reform, Republicans flew home, Democratic leaders held press conference, smiling microphones outside Senate chamber. Reid said, "For wanted protect Wall Street, didn't work." He excused himself: join Biden telephone fund-raiser "some Nevadans." Durbin said, "I stunned four Republicans would join us passing historic legislation. What take bring Republican Party conversation future America?" Dodd, glowing triumph, said, "I wanted demonstrate Senate United States could conduct business much founders intended. We that." On July 21st, President Obama signed completed bill. The two lasting achievements Senate, financial regulation health care, required year half legislative warfare nearly destroyed body. They depended set circumstances—a large majority Democrats, charismatic President electoral mandate, national crisis—that last long repeated anytime soon. Two days financial reform became law, Harry Reid announced Senate would take comprehensive energy-reform legislation rest year. And climate change joined immigration, job creation, food safety, pilot training, veterans' care, campaign finance, transportation security, labor law, mine safety, wildfire management, scores executive judicial appointments list matters world's greatest deliberative body incapable addressing. Already, feel Senate slipping back stagnant waters. How Come havent? This against. Betrayed They said save Afghanistan's women. So come haven't? BY VALERIE M. HUDSON, PATRICIA LEIDL I MAY 10, 2010 One day November 2009, Helmand province's capital Lashkar Gah, group Afghan widows divorcees met Patricia, commissioned write series success stories U.S. Agency International Development (USAID). All women 20s, 30s, 40s looked 60s. Until recently, none could work possessed marketable skills, could neither read write, risk killed left homes. A number women said that, program -- focused tailoring basic literacy -- children used weep night hunger. COMMENTS (22) SHARE: Twitter Reddit Buzz EMore... As Patricia prepared leave, women fluttered around like moths, touching sleeves speaking once. 'What saying?" Pat asked young Pashto-speaking interpreter. "They telling go back country ask people abandon them. The women Afghanistan don't want leave. They quite literally die Taliban return," said. In recent question-and-answer period one universities, Brigham Young, student asked Gen. David Petraeus whether anyone thought ask women Afghanistan felt U.S. hopes incorporate "reformed" Taliban governance structures Americans leave. Carefully avoiding word "women," general assured questioning student "moderate" Taliban would eligible rehabilitation. Left unaddressed definition "moderate," clearly depends sit: If sit burqa, thing "moderate" Taliban. Petraeus might find easy sidestep question happen Afghanistan's women "moderate" Taliban come back, it's likely haunt long time. Without security women security -- we've done protect it, moral practical obligation stay Afghanistan. In 2001, George W. Bush's administration interpreted first post-invasion photos Afghan girls heading school Afghan women unveiling faces tangible evidence conditions improving benighted land. A months invasion, 2002 State Union address, Bush announced, "The last time met chamber, mothers daughters Afghanistan captives homes, forbidden working going school. Today women free part Afghanistan's new government." The Americans strong-armed handful women loya jirga drafted Afghan Constitution. They strong-armed quota women Afghan national legislature -- something even American women treated to. U.S. troops built schools girls pushed women included local shuras, USAID ripped page Greg Mortenson's Three Cups Tea facilitated new training educational opportunities women. But current administration, despite female secretary State new Office Global Women's Issues, appears ditching women Afghanistan like blind date gone bad. You go back 10 months find sustained rhetoric President Barack Obama importance assuring security women Afghanistan. Since then, especially since last year's Afghan election, fine words sitting president disappeared. Many fine actions gone, too. Push local shuras including women 2002? Yes. Push local shuras including women 2010? Forget it. It's difficult understand why. Afghanistan crisis. The cynical policies characterized early mid-stages occupation come home roost. President Hamid Karzai rogue's gallery kleptocrats, human rights abusers, drug lords hanging onto power even Karzai declares open season United Nations accusing senior bureaucrats organizing widespread voter fraud consolidated hold power. In meantime, women taken back seat realpolitik exigencies coalition exit strategy. But suffering real, Afghanistan's poverty chaos affect women possibly all. Matemal mortality Afghanistan still makes world's top three list, nine years U.S. invasion, resulting life expectancy women 46. In countryside, Taliban zealots spray acid girls' faces going school -- 27 percent first place. According recent survey U.N. Development Fund Women, 87 percent Afghan women report beaten regular basis. In July last year, U.N. Assistance Mission Afghanistan (UNAMA) issued report represents stinging official condemnation Karzai administration's abysmal track record women date. The report concluded, "The current reality ... women denied fundamental human rights risk violence course seeking justice crimes perpetrated them." Last year Karzai pardoned well-connected political thugs -- witnesses -- gang-raped woman bayonet. Her husband, battled redress, assassinated soon thereafter. Women dare speak widespread trampling rights face almost certain death murderers face 100 percent impunity. For warlords mujahideen make upper echelons Karzai government, issue gender equality always unwanted appendage U.S. involvement -- one could easily dispensed deployment flowery speeches token appointment lone female minister Ministry Women's Affairs. Indeed, recent "election," Karzai felt secure enough sign law series repressive measures designed repeal minimal gains women made since Taliban ouster. Although eventually forced back legislation allows Shiite husbands rape wives, Karzai successfully signed law legislation denies severely limits women's rights inherit, divorce, guardianship children. The Shiite Personal Status Law also legalizes forced marriage rape minors. It allows men exert almost total control female relatives offers power prohibit women's access work, education, health care denying right leave homes except "legitimate" purposes. Even Karzai's wife -- doctor whose skills desperately needed -- strictly sequestered. And sounds bad, wait Americans leave. This women. Gender inequality affects girls women, boys men. In Afghanistan, women rarely able leave house, young boys often forced carry unwarranted amount financial responsibility, something limits prospects well. Nor even Afghanistan. As Secretary State Hillary Clinton said March, "The subjugation women threat national security United States." On geopolitical level, Valerie's research found states higher levels violence women also less peaceful internationally. Indeed, violence women better predictor bellicosity level democracy, level wealth, presence Islamic civilization. In 2010 study, Valerie, along Brad Thayer, also found high levels gender inequality strong aggravating factor development Islamic suicide terrorism. So, given desperate need Afghanistan's women serious consequences worldwide, aren't help? One reason fallacious notion, common among coalition members, Afghan "culture" allow gender equality forcing issue undermine Western interests. Pat heard openly one coalition representative, prefers remain anonymous: 'There point pushing gender equality. It alienate [Afghans]." Of course, "them" refers men. But decision-makers forget culture fixed, highly mutable dynamic. More 30 years ago, Afghan women attending universities, teaching, working doctors, nurses, professors. Far black hole gender apartheid, Afghanistan, though impoverished, progressive many Muslim neighbors. Furthermore, many young Afghans open new ways things. In 2009, hundreds Afghan men women bravely stood together Kabul protest Karzai's support new oppressive Shiite family law. If Americans assume Afghan men Neanderthals incapable sympathizing plight sisters, wrong. Another, unmentionable reason may chauvinism permeates Western military culture. U.S. military life, despite increasing female recruitment even "female engagement teams," remains bastion masculinity, little sensitivity toward questions female rights. For military leadership recruits alike, immured almost exclusively male world, complete absence women Afghanistan's streets villages elicited comment Marines surrounded Pat, though woman noticed immediately. And ready availability pornography U.S. bases, coupled seamier depictions life West, damages prospects gender equality extension, Western interests. As one young, well-educated 24-year-old Afghan male pointed out, "Your culture respect women all. Look pornography way exploit women ways can't even imagine. Do call progress?" Added another Afghan USAID programmer working Gardez, man 50s father three girls, "It would better coalition could figure way limit kind material." We better -- much better. The Obama administration must instill military personnel senior diplomats necessity fully protecting women's rights. Key educating gender equality furthers Western interests security. The military spend less time courting "moderate" Taliban time showing Afghan community leaders gender equality -- including female access family planning methods -- result healthier families, lower maternal child death rates, poverty alleviation, greater self-determination. Gender included component governance training placed front center upcoming "peace jirga" include Taliban. Indeed, let half negotiating team representing government coalition female: yes, full 50 percent. Women must also represented government. As Melanne Verveer, U.S. ambassador large global women's issues, noted last summer, speaking female politicians Afghanistan, "There one minister cabinet, powerless. There low percentage women civil service. There one female governor, Bamiyan." Obama must insist important changes women leave make subsequent aid contingent upon maintenance strong presence women Afghan government. Better yet, coalition needs support "regime change" building democratic institutions groom moderate, educated middle class young women men eventually take over. Over two-thirds Afghan population age 25, either real opportunity social change -- educated given chance shape society progressive way -- major obstacle, find without jobs, unable marry, burdened retrograde attitudes means male female. We must hold Afghanistan responsible treaty obligations U.N. Convention Elimination Discrimination Women (CEDAVV) U.N. Security Council Resolution 1325 women, peace, security. Afghanistan signed CEDAW without reservations (the United States interestingly, not), means committed passing whatever legislation necessary implement wide-ranging principles gender equality enshrined treaty. This includes taking measures ensure women enjoy basic human rights fundamental freedoms men, place legal judicial procedures protect rights women, taking measures eliminate sexist discrimination, lastly, submitting national reports every four years U.N. advisory group international experts, CEDAW Committee, ensure transparency measures country taken implement treaty's provisions. Unanimously adopted 2000, UNSC 1325 marked first time Security Council recognized disproportionate unique impact armed conflict women stressed importance equal full participation active agents peace security. Needless say, women currently enjoy fundamental freedoms men, indeed, passing Shiite family law, many worse before. To change this, coalition needs stay Afghanistan. Withdrawing critical juncture would doom Afghanistan entire region instability effectively consign one half population premature death existence fit animals. We creating shameful American tradition leaving women better (Afghanistan) -- even much worse (Iraq) -- U.S. troops intervened. On basis America's track record, women around world faith U.S. soldiers improve security. Despite Clinton's remarks link gender equality security, ground Americans act women's well-being, end, peripherally related issue peace. As seen, view could wrong. Verveer's benchmarks concerning Afghanistan right ones: "Progress Afghanistan must measured military terms, also terms social, political, economic participation women rebuilding Afghanistan safeguarding human rights."
