Did Sean. Sid The Political Scene Confounding Fathers The Tea Party's Cold War roots. Sean Wilentz October 18, 2010 ann Beck's view American history stems paranoid politics fifties. A months ago, cable-television radio host Glenn Beck began Fox News show one favorite props: pipe clenched teeth. "I've got pipe," told audience, speech slightly muddled stem, "because we're going speak schoolish kind things." The theme day "Restoring History," Beck, looking professorial neat dark blazer pink button-down shirt, began lesson peering stack history textbooks pronouncing full falsehoods, produced "malicious progressive intent." Progressives, explained—liberals, socialists, Communists, entire spectrum left—"knew separate us history able separate us Constitution God." For next hour, Beck earnestly explained history "is stolen us": depression 1920, example, conservative economics saved nation "near-depression" 1946—crises progressives don't want know about. "You've taught one lie, I think, whole life," said. For fractious Tea Party movement, Beck—a former drive-time radio jockey, recovering alcoholic, Mormon convert—has emerged unifying figure intellectual guide. One opinion poll, released July Democracy Corps, showed "the highly regarded individual among Tea Party supporters," seen merely entertainer, like Rush Limbaugh, "educator." And past months Beck established institute learning: online, for-profit Beck University. Enrollees take courses like Faith 102, contends "revisionists secular progressives" separation church state; Hope 102, attack activist federal government; combined Charity 101/102/103, highly restrictive interpretation rights, federalism, division powers. During "Restoring History" episode, Beck twice encouraged viewers join Web seminars, hear "lessons best brightest historians scholars could find." The B.U. faculty consists three members, including one bona-fide academic, James R. Stoner, Jr., chair political-science department Louisiana State University; two head management consulting firm founder WallBuilders, Web site calls "a national pro-family organization." Beck often acts professor, slightly jocular one, Fox News program. Surrounded charts figures, offers explanations current politics history lessons country's long march Obama-era totalitarianism. The decline, says, began Progressive era early twentieth century, particular Presidency Woodrow Wilson, Federal Reserve System graduated federal income tax came existence. "Wilson," Beck told radio audience August, "just despised America was." Beck's claims found audience among Tea Party spokesmen sympathizers. At movement's Freedom Summit Washington last September, one activist told reporter, "The election Teddy Roosevelt Woodrow Wilson 1912 started going downhill." And April angry member Tea Party Patriots group Cape Fear, North Carolina, claimed group's Web site "the things see happening country today started Wilson Administration." At Tax Day rally past spring, veteran conservative organizer Richard Viguerie described Tea Party "an unfettered new force middle class." And, indeed, calling Obama socialist tradition Woodrow Wilson audacious enough seem like marker new movement—or, least, new twist nation's long history conspiracy-mongering. In fact, marks revival ideas circulated extremist right half century ago, especially John Birch Society among admirers. Beck's version American history relies lessons acknowledged inspiration, late right-wing writer W. Cleon Skousen, also restates charges made Birch Society's founder, Robert Welch. The political universe is, course, different today Cold War. Yet Birchers' politics view American history—which focussed totalitarian threats home posed Soviet Union Communist China—has proved remarkably persistent. The pressing historical question extremist ideas held bay decades inside Republican Party exploded anew—and why, time, Party leaders done virtually nothing challenge ideas, great deal abet them. The early nineteen-sixties turbulent time American politics, right wing particular. In South, racist violence civil-rights workers constant, deepening sectional splits Democratic Party would time deliver solidly Democratic South Republicans. Southern elected officials, support called "massive resistance" civil-rights laws judicial rulings, resurrected ideas nullification interposition, claimed individual states could void federal laws within borders. Others focussed considered fearsome Communist menace inside United States. General Edwin A. Walker caused enormous stir resigned Army 1961, President John F. Kennedy's Pentagon reprimanded spreading right-wing propaganda among troops accusing prominent American officials Communist sympathies. Senator Strom Thurmond, Dixiecrat South Carolina, spoke many far right declared various modestly liberal domestic programs "fall clearly within category socialism." The John Birch Society one decade's controversial right-wing organizations. Founded 1958 Robert Welch, candy manufacturer Massachusetts, society took name Baptist missionary military- intelligence officer killed Communist Chinese forces 1945, Welch called first American casualty Cold War. The group founded propitious time. After Senator Joseph McCarthy's fall, 1954, many McCarthy's followers felt bereft voice, Welch seemed speak them; mid-sixties, society's membership estimated high hundred thousand. Welch, exploiting fears McCarthy called "immense" domestic conspiracy, declared federal government already fallen Communists' clutches. In tract titled "The Politician," attacked President Dwight D. Eisenhower "a dedicated, conscious agent Communist conspiracy" serving plot "all adult life." Late 1961, disastrous Bay Pigs invasion, accused Kennedy Administration "helping Communists everywhere world pretending opposite." Wherever looked, Welch saw Communist forces manipulating American economic foreign policy behalf totalitarianism. But within United States, believed, subversion actually begun years Bolshevik Revolution. Conflating modern liberalism totalitarianism, Welch described government "always inevitably enemy individual freedom." Consequently, charged, Progressive era, expanded federal government's role curbing social economic ills, dire period history, Woodrow Wilson "more one man started nation present road totalitarianism." In nineteen-sixties, Welch became convinced even Communist movement "a tool total conspiracy." This master conspiracy, said, forerunners ancient Sparta, sprang fully life eighteenth century, "uniformly Satanic creed program" Bavarian Illuminati. Run called "the Insiders," conspiracy resided chiefly international families financiers, Rothschilds Rockefellers, government agencies like Federal Reserve System Internal Revenue Service, nongovernmental organizations like Bilderberg Group, Council Foreign Relations, Trilateral Commission. Since early twentieth century, done good deal evil work guise humanitarian uplift. "One broad avenue conspiratorial forces advance known progressive legislation," Welch declared 1966. "The collectivist theories demagogic pretenses destroyed earlier civilizations paraded forth disguise new modern concepts." In worst case, Welch believed, military action might necessary dislodge totalitarians. But moment nonviolent political revolution would suffice. Accordingly, designed Birch Society roughly, explicitly, Marxist-Leninist model vanguard revolutionary party: series small cells would work secret agitate populace elect right-thinking candidates office. "It isn't numbers worry about," Welch wrote, "but courage part followers stick necks play rough—the Communists do." The "Founder" would dictate society's policies, advised council two dozen businessmen professionals, local cells would overseen unyielding commanders. "It leadership demanding, exacting followers," Welch observed, "that achieves really dedicated support." Welch's group became synonymous right-wing extremism, earning satirical blasts critics ranging cartoonist Walt Kelly musicians Bob Dylan Dizzy Gillespie. The trumpeter, whose actual name John Birks Gillespie, made humorous run Presidency 1964, organizing John Birks Societies twenty-five states. Still, outlandish era's right-wing anti-Communists Welch Willard Cleon Skousen. A transplanted Canadian served Mormon missionary teens, Skousen considered radical early nineteen-sixties even J. Edgar Hoover's F.B.I. watched closely; one 1962 memo extensive F.B.I. file noted "during past year so, Skousen affiliated extreme right-wing 'professional communists' promoting anticommunism obvious financial purposes." Skousen employed F.B.I., 1935 1951, much time special agent working chiefly administration. These desk jobs, claimed implausibly, gave access confidential domestic intelligence Communism. Skousen also maintained served Hoover's administrative assistant; Hoover informed inquirers position. Skousen taught years speech religion departments Brigham Young University, interrupted stint, 1956 1960, police chief Salt Lake City. His time office contentious, raided friendly card game attended city's right-wing mayor, J. Bracken Lee, promptly fired. Lee called Skousen "a master half truths" said ran police department "like Gestapo"; Skousen's supporters placed burning crosses Mayor's lawn. After losing police job, Skousen founded group called All-American Society, Time described 1961 exemplar far-right "ultras." Although join Birch Society, Skousen worked American Opinion Speakers' Bureau, and, 1963, wrote rousing tract titled "The Communist Attack John Birch Society," condemned society's critics "promoting official Communist Party line." (This tic Skousen's; later defended Mormon policy denying priesthood blacks pamphlet called "The Communist Attack Mormons.") All along, Skousen's evolving thoughts ran tandem Welch's. In "The Naked Communist," lengthy primer published 1958, enlivened survey worldwide leftist threat outlandish claims, writing F.D.R.'s adviser Harry Hopkins treasonously delivered Soviets large supply uranium, Russians built first Sputnik plans stolen United States. A year Richard Condon's novel "The Manchurian Candidate" appeared, Skousen announced Communists creating "a regimented breed Pavlovian men whose minds could triggered immediate action signals masters." A later book, "The Naked Capitalist," decried Ivy League Establishment, who, Federal Reserve, Council Foreign Relations, Rockefeller Foundation, formed "the world's secret power structure." The conspiracy begun, Skousen wrote, reformers like wealthy banker Edward M. (Colonel) House, close adviser President Woodrow Wilson, helped put place Federal Reserve graduated income tax. In 1971, Skousen organized another group, Freemen Institute, later renamed National Center Constitutional Studies. According article published Review Religious Research, center's targets included "the Occupational Safety Health Administration, Environmental Protection Agency, Federal Communication Commission's fairness doctrine editorial broadcasting, federal government's change gold standard currency, subsidies farmers, federal aid education, federal social welfare, foreign aid, social security, elimination public school prayer Bible reading, (that familiar right-wing nemesis) United Nations." Skousen's pronouncements made pariah among conservative activists, including right-wing fringe. In 1962, ultraconservative American Security Council threw out, members felt "gone deep end." In 1971, review Mormon journal Dialogue accused Skousen "inventing fantastic ideas making inferences go far beyond bounds honest commentary," advancing doctrines came "perilously close" Nazism. And 1979, Skousen called President.Jimmy Carter puppet Council Foreign Relations Rockefeller family, president Mormon church issued national order banning announcements organizations. Skousen undeterred. In 1981, produced "The 5,000 Year Leap," treatise assembles selective quotations groundless assertions claim U.S. Constitution rooted Enlightenment Bible, framers believed minimal central government. Either proposition would astounded James Madison, often described guiding spirit behind Constitution, rejected state-established religions and, like Alexander Hamilton, proposed central government strong could veto state laws. "The 5,000 Year Leap" fervid book. Instead, calmly, ingratiatingly misleading. Skousen quotes various eighteenth-century patriots evils Samuel Adams, 1768, called "the Utopian schemes leveling," Skousen equates redistribution wealth. But mention Founders' endorsement taxing rich support general welfare. Thomas Jefferson, example, wrote approvingly 1811 federal taxes (then limited tariffs) fall solely wealthy, meant "the farmer see government supported, children educated, face country made paradise contributions rich alone, without called spend cent earnings." Skousen also challenges separation church state, asserting "the Founders indulging idle gesture adopted motto 'In God We Trust.' "In reality, motto came Constitutional Convention "E Pluribus Unum": many, one. "In God We Trust" came much later; use coins first permitted 1864, 1955, height Cold War, Congress mandate appear currency. The following year, President Eisenhower—who Welch charged Communist agent—approved "In God We Trust" national motto. In 1982, Skousen published follow-up work, ancestor-worshipping history text titled The Making America," prepared study guide nationwide seminars based contents. As Alexander Zaitchik reports informative study Beck, "Common Nonsense," new book became object controversy 1987, California Bicentennial Commission sold part fund-raising drive. Among offenses account slavery drawn long-disgraced work historian Fred A. Shannon, characterized slave children "pickaninnies" suggested worst victims slavery slaveholders themselves. The constitutional scholar Jack Rakove, Stanford, inspected Skousen's book seminars pronounced "a joke self-respecting scholar would think worth warm pitcher spit." By time Skousen died, 2006, little remembered outside ranks furthest-right Mormons. Then, 2009, Glenn Beck began touting work: "The Naked Communist," "The Naked Capitalist," and, especially, "The 5,000 Year Leap," called "essential understanding Founders built Republic way did." After Beck put book first spot required-reading list—and wrote enthusiastic new introduction reissue— shot top Amazon best-seller list. In first half 2009, sold two hundred fifty thousand copies. Local branches Tea Party Patriots, United American Tea Party, groups across country since organized study groups around it. "It time learn follow FREEDOM principles Founding Fathers," United American Tea Party video declares, referring principles expounded Skousen's book. If Beck movement's teacher, "The 5,000 Year Leap" become primer, "The Making America" kind 102- level text. The popularity Beck's broadcasts, reach two million viewers day, brought neo-Birchite ideas audience beyond Welch Skousen might dreamed of. Several times week, Beck informs audience socialists (whom also sometimes calls Fascists Communists) led Obama seized power, patriotic Americans must take country back. His TV show time featured "Comrade Updates," Beck described perfidy Soviet anthem played background. He attacks familiar bogeymen: Federal Reserve System (which asserts private conglomerate, unaccountable public); Council Foreign Relations (born "progressive idea" manipulate media order "let masses know done"); historical procession evildoers, including Skousen's old target Colonel House Welch's old target Woodrow Wilson. His sources matters, quite apart Skousen's books, unreliable. On September 22nd, amid diatribe House, Beck cited passage "Secrets Federal Reserve," Eustace Mullins. The book, commissioned 1948 Ezra Pound, startlingly anti-Semitic fantasy Jewish-led conspiracy all-powerful bankers established Federal Reserve service plot dominate world. Part Beck's allure promise reveal secret information. In one segment last year, produced drawing fasces—which described, anachronistically, "the Roman symbol Fascism"—and picture old Mercury dime, fasces reverse side. "Who brought dime in? It happened 1916—Woodrow Wilson President," said. "We've road Fascism while." Benito Mussolini, course, didn't adopt ancient symbol authority Fascist emblem nineteen-twenties; designer coin, sculptor Adolph A. Weinman, intended signify nation's military preparedness, paired olive branch illustrate desire peace. Beck's readings Progressive-era politics nearly bizarre. Whatever said Theodore Roosevelt, crypto-radical. It Roosevelt coined term "lunatic fringe" describe extreme leftists day, concept New Nationalism—in activist government built vibrant capitalism, partly regulating big business—looked back Alexander Hamilton, Karl Marx. Nor Wilson Bolshevik; fact, 1917 sent American troops Russia support anti-Bolshevik White Army. At home, reforms sought break monopolies order restore competition among small companies. "If America free enterprise," Wilson declared, "then freedom sort whatever." In 2007, Beck, host "Glenn Beck," CNN's Headline News, brought show John Birch Society spokesman named Sam Antonio, warned government plot abolish U.S. borders Mexico Canada, "and eventually throughout Americas." Beck told Antonio, "When I growing up, John Birch Society—I thought bunch nuts." But now, said, "you guys starting make sense me." His guest beamed. "Yes, John Birch Society nuts," Antonio said. "We exposing truth that's many, many years." Since then, Birch Society's Web site run clips Beck's Fox broadcasts, proudly pointing similarities ideas. Last June, essay site described presentation Beck Communism America "the ultimate complete agreement Beck JBS presentations American history." Beck also praised Ezra Taft Benson, one Skousen's close associates. Benson, Secretary Agriculture President Eisenhower thirteenth president Church Jesus Christ Latter-Day Saints, gained notoriety speech 1966 denounced Democratic officeholders intellectuals (including historian Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr.) socialists Communist sympathizers, warned "the Constitution endangered hang, were, single thread," praised John Birch Society "the effective non-church organization fight creeping socialism Godless Communism." Last June, Beck aired clip another Benson speech, intoning, "Ezra Taft Benson warned coming." The Birch Society's Web site subsequently praised Beck "getting progressively (sorry bad word choice) closer presenting American history way The John Birch Society 50 years." Beck sole representative today's multifaceted Tea Party Welch Skousen nineteen- sixties far right; recently told Times, bit disingenuously, "not involved Tea Party." Why, then, politics Skousen, Benson, John Birch Society resurgence among conservative Republicans—not Beck Tea Party heroes like Nevada Republican Senate candidate Sharron Angle? (Last month, Angle gave warm address "freedom conference" Salt Lake City, co-sponsored John Birch Society Skousen's old group, National Center Constitutional Studies, praising audience "mainstream America" patriots "heard call.") The columnist Frank Rich, among others, suggested election black President sowed "fears disenfranchisement among dwindling threatened minority country." There signs so: Republicans' singling Thurgood Marshall "activist Justice" Elena Kagan's Supreme Court confirmation hearings, warnings Fox News terrible dangers posed minuscule New Black Panther Party. But "socialist" racial slur. Jim Crow built fears Federal Reserve I.R.S. The Tea Party's fulminations cap-and-trade, federal-government bailouts, big government generally play old themes nothing color President Obama's skin. The current right-wing resurgence inner dynamics American conservatism past half century. In nineteen-fifties nineteen-sixties, far right condemned liberals, might expected; November, 1961, President Kennedy devoted part speech Los Angeles denouncing "discordant voices extremism" "equate Democratic Party welfare state, welfare state socialism, socialism Communism." But Bircher right also provoked deep anxiety among conservatives, feared perceived paranoids conspiracy-mongers. The leading intellectual spokesman organizer anti-Bircher conservatives William F. Buckley, Jr., editor National Review. Buckley means moderate conservatism. He lifelong defender Joseph McCarthy foe New Deal liberalism. But drew line claiming course American government set socialist conspiracy, feared ravings extreme right would cost balanced, practical conservatives chance national power. "By 1961," biographer John B. Judis writes, "Buckley beginning worry John Birch Society growing rapidly, right-wing upsurge country would take ugly, even Fascist turn rather leading toward kind conservatism National Review promoted." In next two decades, Buckley's support counsel, Richard Nixon Ronald Reagan completed conservative revolution succeeded keeping extremist elements far centers power. As confidant adviser leading conservative politicians, Buckley far political influence might expected editor weekly journal. Yet early nineteen-sixties found fighting Birchers fellow-travellers extremely difficult. Even though Buckley's colleagues National Review thought Birch Society went far, would attack society publicly, fear alienating Birchers conservatives sympathized views. When Buckley wrote editorial 1962 accused Welch "distorting reality" failing make "the crucial moral political distinction" Communists liberals, magazine immediately lost subscriptions financial support. By 1960, Senator Barry Goldwater, Arizona, emerging great political hope conservative Republicans, consulted closely Buckley. At meeting Breakers hotel, Palm Beach, January, 1962, Buckley urged Goldwater repudiate Birch Society. Goldwater demurred; though conceded embarrassing "kooks" lurked among Birchers, insisted Buckley also "nice guys," would injudicious attack group public. The Birchers' support helped gain Goldwater Republican Presidential nomination 1964, winked acceptance speech famous line: "Extremism defense liberty vice. . . . Moderation pursuit justice virtue." In general election, though, Goldwater suffered crushing loss Lyndon Johnson, partly Democrats succeeded making look like captive loony right. (To Goldwater slogan "In Your Heart, You Know He's Right," Democrats shot back, "In Your Guts, You Know He's Nuts.") Buckley's fears confirmed. But undeterred efforts build respectable viable conservative movement. In 1967, favored Richard Nixon among field Republican aspirants. He liked Ronald Reagan's politics, considered Reagan, recently elected governor California, new national politics. George Romney, governor Michigan, wishy- washy moderate, obviously unsuitable, say nothing Republican archliberal Nelson Rockefeller, New York. Nixon hard-nosed Republican strong conservative views, especially Communism Cold War; established Communist-hunter nineteen-forties pressing charge Alger Hiss, former official State Department, spied Soviets. And, promisingly, Nixon front-runner. "It seems ought real chance winning year," Buckley wrote Goldwater around time Republican National Convention. He served campaign adviser, aiding friend Frank Shakespeare, taken charge Nixon's media operations. But Buckley's candidate reputation shiftiness made unpopular across political spectrum. Some editors National Review, recalling Nixon cut deal Rockefeller order secure G.O.P. nomination 1960, didn't sufficiently trust him. And Birch Society nothing contempt figure Welch called one "the slipperiest politicians ever showed American scene." As President, 1969, Nixon began open diplomatic relations Communist China, right wing placed list perfidious appeasers. When visited Beijing 1972, even Buckley deeply offended. But general election took place later year, antiwar Democratic candidate, George McGovern, voicing country's anxieties Vietnam, Buckley mainstream called "responsible conservatism" returned Nixon. The purist conservatives left back third-party candidacy John Schmitz, Republican congressman member John Birch Society. Nixon won landslide, next year appointed Buckley American delegate United Nations. The conservative pragmatists found way real power. And, despite embarrassment Watergate, Nixon's second term, strategy proved effective time. Nixon's campaign McGovern sharpened Democrats' internal divisions civil rights Vietnam, and, Buckley wrote, revealed Democrats "an indifference toward national independence hostility toward national freedom." Meanwhile, Buckley mainstream, read Birchers conservative movement, established permanent growing force Republican Party national politics. In 1976, Buckley National Review supported Ronald Reagan's primary challenge Nixon's successor, Gerald Ford. After two terms governor, Reagan matured Buckley considered nearly ideal conservative politician: shrewd leader well man principle. Reagan nearly succeeded wresting nomination Ford, demonstrating formidable national figure become. The Bircher right flourished political bastion Orange County, Reagan adept winning extremists' allegiance pursued realistic strategies. His pragmatic side showed immediately finally secured Republican nomination 1980, chose relatively moderate George H. W. Bush, bitter foe primaries, running mate. Though decision dismayed right-wing ideologues, two practical benefits: instantly healed divisions Republican moderates conservatives, helped dampen charges Democrats Reagan reckless right- winger. Nobody pleased Bush's selection fellow Skull Bones man William F. Buckley, understood political logic clearly Reagan had. As President, Reagan flattered extremists—he even delivered admiring words Skousen's Freemen Institute—but saved political capital real goals: undoing fiscal underpinnings New Deal-style government, redirecting U.S. foreign policy battling Soviet Union proxies around world. He appointed moderates positions importance, made James Baker III, Bush's close associate, first chief staff, rather far ideological Edwin Meese III, former chief staff California. (As top policy adviser, Meese helped Reagan stack federal bench conservatives, otherwise eclipsed Baker Baker's deputy, pragmatic Reaganite Michael Deaver, crusade, Attorney General, roll back civil-rights legislation largely failed.) When zealots Administration exposed, Iran-Contra scandal, Reagan skillfully evaded responsibility replaced centrist Republicans. And, recognized Mikhail Gorbachev Soviet leader could undertake genuine efforts reduce nuclear threat, Reagan pushed forward, ignoring complaints become, hard-liner Howard Phillips's phrase, "a useful idiot Soviet propaganda." Whatever misgivings may arisen right, Reagan achieved dramatic conservative overhaul federal tax code, profound reconfiguring judiciary, near-victory West Cold War. From standpoint mainstream right, problem legacy Republican could come close matching public appeal political savvy. For party Reagan, departure beginning long decline, absence similarly totemic figure, past twenty years, allowed current resurgence extremism. George H. W. Bush repelled right-wingers moderate tendencies—not least when, face fiscal calamity, broke campaign pledge raise taxes. Bill Clinton inspired almost ecstatic series attacks, though remained enough older conservative establishment, personified Senator Bob Dole, check wildest charges, new Republican House majority 1994, pushed ideologues Tom DeLay Dick Armey, little interest maintaining center. They harassed Clinton, forcing impeachment even though polls showed sixty per cent American people disapproved. George W. Bush seemed first bit Reagan's conservative charisma, right wing turned failing win war Iraq, moderate position immigration, spending hundreds millions federal dollars combat financial collapse 2008. When William F. Buckley died, 2008 primary season, seemed symbolize end conservative era. David Klinghoffer, former literary editor National Review, lamented "urbane visionaries builders institutions" Buckley replaced media figures "who make money stirring fears resentments." Conservatism, Klinghoffer added, "has undergone shift toward demagoguery hucksterism," ruled called "the crazy-cons." Some Republicans tried extend Buckley tradition, little effect. The commentator David Frum, former speechwriter George W. Bush, lost job American Enterprise Institute complained Republicans' obstruction health-care reform called right-wing surge threat conservatism. In June, congressman Bob Inglis, South Carolina, tough conservative nonetheless backed Bush's financial bailout, lost vicious primary fight right-wing insurgent named Trey Gowdy. To amazement, Inglis confronted campaign trail voters convinced numbers Social Security cards indicated secret bank bought birth. "And then, course," recalls, "it turned something Federal Reserve Bilderbergers stuff." Not even Karl Rove afford open dissent Tea Partiers. Appearing Fox News night recent primaries, described Tea Party-backed Senate candidate Delaware, Christine O'Donnell, probably unelectable said statements "nutty." Instantly, criticism came Sarah Palin, Rush Limbaugh, right-wing Republicans. Within days, back Fox, proclaiming "a huge Tea Party fan," endorsing O'Donnell, affirming National Republican Senatorial Committee would give full backing. So far, Rove, unlikely dissident, prominent Republican leader much gesture stepping forward, Buckley allies did. Even strong conservatives like Inglis pushed aside, former G.O.P. stalwarts Charlie Crist, Florida, Mike Castle, Delaware, beaten primaries Tea Party candidates; Grist running long-shot campaign Independent. Desperate gains midterm elections, Republicans neglecting struggle took make politics safe Reagan. Fifty years ago, President Kennedy deplored far right's "counsels fear suspicion." Today, Obama's White House still struggling make sense enemies. In absence forthright leadership, right left, job standing extremists appears left electorate. Candidates like O'Donnell may prove eccentric prevail, voters may simply become disillusioned politicians campaign hatred government. After election, mainstream conservatives may well engage Richard Viguerie forecast "a massive, almost historic battle heart soul Republican Party." (Already, Rove leading Bush political operatives, including former Republican National Committee chairman Ed Gillespie, quietly supplanting battered G.O.P. establishment effort raise funds year's candidates.) But, according recent poll, seventy per cent Republicans support Tea Party, seems almost certain Republican Party unstintingly appeased far right enjoy strong perhaps smashing victory coming midterm elections. In 1906, early Progressive era, humorist Finley Peter Dunne's fictional barroom sage, Mr. Dooley, put social political tumult day perspective. "Th' noise ye hear th' first gun iv revolution," Dooley remarked. "It's on'y th' people iv th' United States batin' carpet." A century now, even year now, Americans may say Tea Party. For moment, though, appears extreme right wing verge securing degree power Congress Republican Party unprecedented modern American history. For defenders national cohesion tempered adversity politics, alarming state affairs. • Read http://www.newyorker.com/reportinq/2010/10/18/101018fa fact wilentz?printable=true#ixzz123hWc5bz

The Huffington Post October 12, 2010 oward Fineman finemanAhuffingtonpost.com I HuffPost Reporting The Power Of Clinton, The Invisibility Of Obama First Posted: 10-12-10 02:37 PM I Updated: 10-12-10 02:37 PM LOUISVILLE -- I see Dr. Rand Paul taken Bill Clinton, dredging Monica Lewinsky. And I know Paul so. The former president Kentucky yesterday state, many others, far potent popular foe President Barack Obama. On first day working The Huffington Post, I came back Kentucky, I began career many years ago Courier-Journal. I know I'm supposed lift head QDDR, thought would like see — it's ideas wanted promoted picked me. AM The Crossroads Nation By DAVID BROOKS Bill Clinton used talk building bridge 21st century. President Obama talks laying "new foundation." But Clinton always vague land side bridge going look like, Obama vague edifice going go top foundation. They vague nobody clear sort country America going 2030 2050. Nobody quite defined America's coming economic identity. In thinking question, probably helps start beginning. Five hundred years ago, agriculture major economic activity. One hundred years ago, industrial production. Now, course, we're living information age. Innovation creativity engines economic growth. Howard Gardner Harvard put together composite picture extraordinarily creative person: She comes little place somewhat removed center power influence. As adolescent, feels outgrowing small circle. She moves metropolis finds group people share passions interests. She gets involved team create something amazing. Then, point, finds problem, related yet different problems concern others group. She breaks struggles finally emerges new thing. She brings back circle. It tested, refined improved. The main point composite story creativity solitary process. It happens within networks. It happens talented people get together, idea systems mentalities merge. Now imagine creative person year 2010, 2025 2050. You living small town Ukraine Kenya place, foreign domestic. You long break go place people gathering think things thinking about, creating things want create. If passionate fashion, maybe go Paris. If it's engineering, maybe it'll Germany. But passionate many spheres, I suspect you'll want America. You'll want U.S. English become global language. You'll want come American universities lead world research draw many best minds corners earth. You'll want American institutions relatively free corruption. Intellectual property protected. Huge venture capital funds already exist. Moreover, United States universal nation. There already people connections world. A nation immigrants permeable say, Chinese society. You also observe America hosts right kind networks — ones flexible intense. Study study suggests America one societies high social trust. Americans build large, efficient organizations bound circles kinship clan. Study study finds Americans hierarchical. American children raised challenge parents. American underlings relatively free challenge bosses. In country you're less likely submit authority. From story see economic power 21st century going look like economic power 20th century. The crucial fact new epoch creativity needs hubs. Information networks need junction points. The nation make crossroads world tremendous economic political power. In 2009, Anne-Marie Slaughter, director policy planning State Department, wrote essay Foreign Affairs laid logic new situation: "In networked world, issue longer relative power, centrality increasingly dense global web." Slaughter's essay titled "America's Edge." That apt. Americans depressed state mind. As China India rise, nearly two-thirds Americans believe nation decline. In fact, U.S. well situated crossroads nation. It well situated center global networks nurture right kinds networks. Building America means everything possible thicken connections: finance research attract scientists; improve infrastructure ease travel; fix immigration funnel talent; reform taxes attract superstars; make study abroad rite passage college students; take advantage millions veterans served overseas. The nation thickest expansive networks define age. There's reason pessimistic that.

http://www.opendemocracy.net/max-blumenthal/days-of-raqe-tea-party-and-american-conservatism Days rage: Tea Party & America's right Blumenthal begin skype highlighting end skype highlighting, 17 September 2010 About author Max Blumenthal begin_of_the_skype_highlighting end_of_the_skype_highlighting journalist whose work published New York Times, Daily Beast, Nation, Huffington Post, Salon, publications. He author Republican Gomorrah: Inside Movement Shattered Party (Basic/Nation Books, 2009). His website Subjects: • Democracy government • International politics • United States • democracy & power • american power & world • rise new right The rise Tea Party movement United States first twenty months Barack Obama '5 presidency shaking political establishment, trend reinforced victories candidates Republican Party primaries. But movement come from, inner life? Max Blumenthal begin_of the_skype highlighting end the_skype highlighting, author "Republican Gomorrah", enters heady world Tea Party unravel mix driven personalities, feverish rhetoric, toxic hatreds, flirtation violence fuel sub-culture's insurgent activism. "He tell wants strong authority take crushing responsibility thinking himself. Since Republic weak, led break law love obedience. But really strong authority wishes? In reality demands rigorous order others, disorder without responsibility" - Jean-Paul Sartre, Anti- Semite Jew I sure I first detected noxious fumes would envelop conservative movement Barack Obama era. It might April 2009, I visited series gun shows rural California Nevada. Perusing tables piled high high-calibre semi-automatic weapons chatting anyone vicinity, I heard urgent warnings mass roundups, concentration-camps, socialist government Washington. "These people purchasing guns people worried what's going country", gun dealer told outside show Reno. "Good luck Obama", young gun enthusiast remarked me. "We outnumber 100 1." At time, Tea Party movement even registered national media's radar. In September 2009, I led panel discussion University California-Riverside book Republic Gomorrah (Basic/Nation Books, 2009). Inside auditorium filled nearly 100 students faculty, I sat alongside Jonathan Walton, African-American professor religious studies prolific writer, Mark Takano, erudite, openly gay former Democratic congressional candidate local community-college trustee. In middle discussion, dozen college Republicans stormed front stage signs denouncing "left-wing hack" hysterical young man leaped crowd, blowing kisses mockingly Takano heckling Walton "racist". Afterward, university police-officers insisted escorting ride right-wing heckler attempted follow shouted threats. Who stalker? Just concerned citizen worried taxes? His name Ryan Sorba operative heavily funded national conservative youth outfit, Intercollegiate Studies Institute. Besides founding dozens Republican youth groups across country, Sorba devoted exceptional amount energy interest homosexuals. His intellectual output consists tract titled The Born Gay Hoax, arguing homosexuality curable disease bogus trend manufactured academic leftists. Adding credentials, Sorba history run-ins law, explained I called order. My encounter aggressive right-wing cadre seemed strange, isolated event. But hostility turned symptomatic intensifying campaign delegitimise President Obama allies Congress. The right's days rage beginning. The constellation Through first year office, Obama seemed oblivious threat far right. He campaigned partisanship, declaring "no red states" "conservative America". Apparently, thought merely contrivance myth people rejected science, demonised gays, assailed minority women's rights - genuinely believed said. Speaking changing Washington, Obama seemed think entire history politics since rise Ronald Reagan right strategies polarisation deeply rooted superficial problem attributable certain "divisive" personalities, easily wiped away gestures toward bipartisanship. His view parties simply mirror images sharing fundamental beliefs separated "partisans". The skilled devoted community organiser could bring together. Many supporters media, often partisans political wars years, reinforced amplified innocence, proclaiming one last could "bridge partisan divide". Andrew Sullivan, disaffected conservative called critics George W Bush policies "fifth columnists" fervently supported Obama, wrote new president destined become "a liberal Reagan reunite America". This optimism pervaded White House new president aides sought Republicans willing vote programmes. After all, couldn't get along? In autobiographical book The Audacity Hope, Obama highlighted key component political strategy: "I serve blank screen people vastly different political stripes project views." Once elected, conservatives concluded could reverse Obama's strength transforming human tableau fearsome images could conjure (see "Barack Obama, fallen messiah", 23 December 2009). Obama's multiracial background crucial cultivating resentment among shock-troops. Those rejected Obama's legitimacy serve president basis background gave birth "Birther" movement sought challenge citizenship. The movement's visible figure, therefore eccentric, Orly Taitz, dentist self-trained lawyer immigrated former Soviet republican Moldova Israel settling conservative bastion Orange County, California. Convinced claims far-right website WorldNetDaily Obama planned create "civilian national security force", Taitz told "realised Obama another Stalin - it's cross Stalinist USSR Hitler's Germany." After becoming transfixed online conspiracy theories claiming Obama's family forged birth-certificate Hawaii, Taitz snapped action. She filed lawsuit November 2008 California's secretary state Debra Bowen demanding investigation Obama's eligibility serve president. Taitz's plaintiff case Wiley Drake, Orange County radio-preacher former second vice-president Southern Baptist Convention publicly prayed Obama's death. While lawsuit went nowhere, subsequent suits earned angry rebukes judges, Taitz became instant media sensation, delivering heavily accented screeds Obama friendly interviewers Sean Hannity CNN's Lou Dobbs (the latter, described Taitz "greatest supporter", eventually fired indirect result hosting her). In March 2009, Texas Representative Randy Neugebauer signed Birther bill proposing future presidential candidates must prove citizenship becoming eligible campaign. The Birther movement found voice government made indelible impact Republican grassroots. By June 2009, 28% Republican respondents Kos/Research 2000 poll said thought Obama wasn't born United States, 30% "weren't sure". "Obama Big House", Taitz shrieked me, "not White House!" When Obama announced healthcare reform first major initiative administration, conservative movement activated campaign demonisation - transformational politics - designed turn Obama "Other", making seem unfamiliar, therefore threatening, possible. When president urged Congress deliver healthcare-reform bill 2009, right staged living theatre political hatred turned Obama's dream bipartisanship nightmarish version Peter Weiss's MaraVSade. On 12 September 2009, tens thousands far- right activists belonging loose confederation anti-government groups called Tea Party Patriots converged Washington's National Mall giant protest Obama healthcare plan. The date significant: Fox News's top-ranked talk-show host Glenn Beck declared birth "9-12 Project" restore sense unity (and siege mentality) Americans experienced 11 September 2001. But time, Obama - Osama - enemy. While covering rally, I witnessed sign sign declaring Obama greater danger America's security al-Qaida; demonstrators held images juxtaposed Obama's face images evildoers Hitler Pol Pot Bin Laden; others carried signs questioning Obama's status United States citizen. "We fight al-Qaida, can't kill Obama", said aging demonstrator. Another told me, "Obama biggest Nazi world", pointing placards fashioned depicting Obama House Representatives' majority leader Nancy Pelosi SS outfits. According another activist, Obama's agenda similar Hitler's: "Hitler took banking industry, not? And Hitler personal secret service police. [The community-organising group] Acorn extension that." The seemingly incongruous Tea Party propaganda recalled signs waved right-wing Jewish settlers rallies Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin support peace process, portraying SS officer French collaborator Marshall Petain. In 1995, amid provocative atmosphere, young right-wing Jewish zealot assassinated Rabin. The Israeli tragedy cautionary example targeted hatred leading violence. Members Tea Party "Patriots" seem care rhetoric irrational, comparing Obama Hitler Stalin contradictory obviously hyperbolic. Their motives entirely negative. By purging government multicultural evil seized power illicit means (several activists told believed Acorn helped Obama steal election), convinced mythical golden American yesteryear would return. They interest building anything new even articulating agenda, much less discussing merits policies. The Tea Party's primary concern cultural purification - freedom from, freedom to. Against dark image president liberal allies, Tea Party activists defined children light. The racial subtext always transparent. The Tea Party's strategy rested guerrilla campaign chaos sabotage designed intimidate Democrats also disorient independent voters might supported healthcare reform. The Tea Paters convinced would easy feat, since believed majority country side - represented "real America". At 9-12 rally Matt Kibbe, one march organisers, told crowd ABC News reporting 1 million 1.5 million people attendance; ABC denied this, saying "ABCNews.com reported approximate figure 60,000 70,000 protesters." Then one Dick Armey led crowd chant "Freedom works! Freedom works!" Unknown Tea Paters, intoning name corporate-funded Beltway advocacy- group, battle-cry Mel Gibson's version William Wallace Bra veheart. Indeed, contrary image grassroots movement mobilised stifle machinations Washington elites, Tea Party movement creation constellation industry-funded conservative groups close Republican ties. The movement's leading puppet-master Dick Armey, directed resources talking-points Tea Party "Patriots" Washington-based advocacy group, FreedomWorks. Among corporate clients Armey's lobbying firm, forced leave result involvement Tea Parties, pharmaceutical giant Bristol Myers Squibb, company clear interest defeating healthcare reform. (Armey's "real American" clients included Marxist terror-cult, People's Mojahedin Iran, received funding assistance Saddam Hussein order launch terrorist strikes throughout 1990s Iranian civilian targets.) Armey collected consulting fee $250,000 directly FreedomWorks $300,000 allied astroturf front groups. FreedomWorks paid much money assortment Republican political consultants. The rumour If Dick Armey Tea Party king, Sarah Palin eager crowned Tea Party queen. Just days Obama's inauguration, Palin abruptly quit job Alaskan governor vie honour. Palin's motives quitting became clear inked lucrative deal write political memoir Going Rogue, signed regular contributor Fox News, received $1 million episode reality-show cable television, "Sarah Palin's Alaska". Palin's book-tour, sent Middle America luxuriously outfitted bus, resembled presidential campaign travelling carnival. Whether Palin intends run president, growing media presence magnified influence within Republican Party. Yet ever-expanding Palin phenomenon greeted hostility Republican politicos desperately seeking expand party's base drubbing 2008. Steve Schmidt, formerly John McCain's campaign manager doomed presidential campaign 2008, warned Palin's nomination 2012 would "catastrophic" GOP. His doomsday prediction backed Gallup poll October 2009 revealing one polarising unpopular political figures country disapproval rating 50%. (During recent interview, Skousen's son, Paul, told contrary rumours Hoover's cross-dressing homosexual dalliances, would set top cop blind dates live women.) Alexander Zaitchik observed authoritative profile Skousen Salon Skousen's renewed influence Beck Tea Party "suggests modern base Republican Party headed strange place." The descent Besides influencing Beck, Skousen's teachings inspired one Tea Party movement's visible grassroots celebrities, retired sheriff Richard Mack. I met Mack February far-right rally outside Montgomery, Alabama. On makeshift stage towed middle rodeo arena pickup truck, Mack recalled reverence mentorship Skousen, said taught everything needed know constitution. Mack urged spellbound audience stockpile ammo store food. "If control food supply", Mack warned, "you control people. And that's first step slavery." Already hero conservatives successfully suing Clinton administration provision Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act requiring law enforcement conduct criminal-background checks gun purchasers, Mack reemerged Obama era archetypal local lawman vowed resist tyrannical federal government. Along dozen former active military law-enforcement personnel, Mack helped form self-styled Tea Party militia called Oathkeepers. Galvanised fear creeping socialism, Oathkeepers solemnly swore refuse tyrannical federal orders cooperating foreign troops forcing Americans concentration-camps. Because group's members trained combat, vow came suggestion armed resistance. Besides Mack, Oathkeepers attracted coterie militia-movement retreads ranks. The well-established figure Mike Vanderboegh, longtime militia fanatic published booklet mid-1990s entitled Strategy Tactics fora Militia Civil War, calling sniper attacks "war criminals, secret policemen, rats." With Obama office, Vandeboegh churned anti-government screeds right-wing blogs renewed passion supported efforts cashing $1,300 federal disability compensation received month. For energy far right exerted campaign strangle Obama's agenda, Democrat posed greatest threat passage healthcare reform. Representative Bart Stupak Michigan office since 1993, placing among senior leadership so-called centrist Blue Dog Democrats. When healthcare reform introduced Congress, Stupak became leader informal caucus anti-abortion Democrats, making de facto swing vote House version bill. By extension, Stupak point man campaign ensure bill would allow federal funding abortion low-income women. But close consultation leaders US Conference Catholic Bishops, Stupak went step further. He introduced draconian amendment block women paying abortions even private insurance plans. The amendment, passed House shut Senate, became key sticking point healthcare negotiations. "He's big hero pro-life community", Deal Hudson - former Catholic issues adviser George W Bush - told November 2009. "Thanks him, first time I remember pro-life Democrats power." To chagrin Republicans, Stupak entertained offers compromise Democratic leadership. According Hudson, Catholic bishops keen see healthcare reform pass, bill contained clear provision forbidding patients spending federal money abortion. Finally, March 2010, pressure Nancy Pelosi, Obama agreed sign executive order forbidding federal funding abortion. Stupak mollified. Now anti-abortion caucus pledged deliver swing votes Democrats needed pass bill. As soon reports seeped declaring imminent passage healthcare reform, major right-wing blogs like RedState.org churned virulent denunciations Stupak, calling traitor sellout. The blog comment sections filled dozens diatribes referring Stupak language previously reserved Dr George Tiller: "Bart Baby-Killer." On 20 March 2010, thousands Tea Party activists surrounded Capitol's Longworth Building expectation Obama's pep talk House Democrats healthcare vote. Democratic Representative John Lewis, hero civil-rights movement, Representative Barney Frank, first openly gay member Congress, passed crowd way inside Capitol. "Nigger!" demonstrator barked Lewis. Another called Frank "faggot", eliciting laughter cheers nearby protesters. Meanwhile, another African-American Democrat, Representative Emanuel Cleaver, ascended Capitol steps, protester screaming Lewis Frank spat face. With demonstration carried night, cries "Kill bill!" drifted calls violence. "I would gladly stand men take fascists down", man camouflage battle-dress uniform proclaimed front amateur videographer, pointing toward Capitol. "You haven't heard last me!" The next day, Republican members Congress emerged Longworth Building salute Tea Paters. The demonstrators cheered wildly proxies inside. Finally, hours impassioned speeches House floor, bill passed. But drama hardly over. Republican Representative Joe Pitts, anti-abortion Catholic co-authored Stupak's original amendment, demanded motion bring back floor vote, transparent exercise grandstanding certain fail. In response, Stupak rushed podium stinging rebuke Pitts Republicans. "The motion commit support life", Stupak declared. "It Democrats stood up...." Heckling Republican side interrupted statement. As Stupak looked around House chamber, Representative Randy Neugebauer, right-wing Republican Texas openly supported Birther movement, began shouting backbench, "Baby killer!" Other Republicans joined in, parroting base insults. While Republicans sank heads defeat, militant devotees Tea Party movement called right-wing Kristallnacht. "If wish send message Pelosi party cannot fail hear, break windows", Vanderboegh Oathkeepers wrote far-right blog hours bill passed. "Break NOW. Break run break again." Within three days, windows doors Democratic Party headquarters New York, Kansas Arizona shattered. Meanwhile, least ten Democratic members Congress reported receiving death threats. Images nooses faxed offices Stupak James Clyburn, African-American congressman South Carolina. Representative Anthony Weiner, especially vocal proponent healthcare reform, received menacing letter filled white powder. The brother Representative Tom Perriello, another healthcare supporter, home gas line deliberately sabotaged local Tea Party organiser posted address online (he meant post congressman's) encouraged activists "drop by" express anger Perriello's recent vote. In Tucson, Arizona, windows Democratic Representative Gabrielle Giffords' office shattered shots pellet gun. And brick thrown window Representative Louise Slaughter's office New York voicemail filled threats impending sniper attacks. After passage healthcare bill, Tea Party floated grey zone authoritarianism anarchy. Crusading restore holy social order, promoted disorder. Claiming protect democracy, smashed windows elected representatives. Warning death panels, called death threats. With atmosphere violence thickening, Palin took Twitter account issue battle-cry: "Don't Retreat, Instead-RELOAD!" Thus concluded first phase Obama era usher peaceable kingdom bipartisanship.

Keith Richards Has Memories Burn By JANET MASLIN It 3 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time New York office Keith Richards's manager, place might look ordinary every wall shelf crammed world's glorious rock 'n' roll memorabilia. Mr. Richards 3 o'clock appointment. "Come in, he'll minute," assistant says — comes minute, 3:01. This man prided operating Keith Time, in: security staff ate shepherd's pie Keith wanted dressing room? Then everyone packed stadium bloody well wait. The Rolling Stones don't play another shepherd's pie shows up. Chalk promptness man's new incarnation: Keith Richards, distinguished author. True, far rock star turn memoirist, far Rolling Stone write book — much himself. The raven-haired Ron Wood wrote "Ronnie," described Brian Jones "me blond wig." Bill Wyman, band's retired bass player bean counter, wrote "Stone Alone," 15-shilling demo disc went unmentioned. Now Mr. Richards written keeper: "Life," big, fierce, game-changing account Stones' nearly half-century-long adventure. "It's difficult thing I've ever done," says book. "I'd rather make ro records." But sounds anything weary. And seems refreshed, bearing surprisingly little resemblance battered, kohl- eyed pirate Keith Richards looks like 50 miles bad road. Today, neutral street clothes hot-green shoes, positively debonair. On hands: ubiquitous silver skull ring, swollen knuckles, thin white scar hunk steaming phosphorus burned finger bone played concert without stopping. On head: headband raffish, straw-colored hat, gray tufts poking directions. Not single gewgaw hangs it. "I've phase," says. "Don't know hair take pressure anymore." He's quite lot phases. And they're page "Life": Boy Scout (really); tyro rocker; lovestruck kid (mad Ronnie Spector, unbeknownst Phil Spector); astonished new star; heroin-addicted older one; jaded veteran countless world tours; longtime sparring partner Mick Jagger. (Despite tabloid shock bickering book, two seriously calling names least since early 198os.) All recounted straight-up candor, easily sensationalized. But book's single biggest stunner hand-written note jacket flap: "Believe not, I haven't forgotten it." How, asked, humanly possible man well known stupefaction "Satisfaction?" "I think main concern beginning whether memory really reliable," says. "Fox little sleuthing." Fox James Fox, journalist author "White Mischief," Mr. Richards's friend many years collaborator putting "Life" together. (It sold Little, Brown & Company reported advance $7 million.) Mr. Fox wound researching Mr. Richards's past, conducting interviews knew long ago drawing upon wonderfully candid old letters journal entries. "Spent day practising," 19-year-old Mr. Richards wrote January 1963, Stones beginning play public. "Worthwhile, I hope!" Also exhumed: 1962 letter Mr. Richards Aunt Patty describing boy known primary school, Mick Jagger. He signs "Luff/Keith XXXXX" These artifacts turned Richards equivalent Proust's madeleines, though Mr. Richards, whose reading taste runs naval history novels Patrick O'Brian George MacDonald Fraser, would hardly put way. In case prompted recollections never expected rediscover, "Life" began click. Once stories told draft written, Mr. Fox wound sitting together separate copies manuscript Mr. Fox read B6 whole book aloud. "What I couldn't guess he'd good natural editor," Mr. Fox, reached e- mail, says Mr. Richards. "He cut, accordingly, pace rhythm — real musical cut." As calling book "Life," Mr. Richards editing too. "My Life" book called. "I said 'I tell what, cut 'My,' you've got title," says. He might appropriately used another title likes, "Keep It Dark." But, says, "I'm saving song." The contents "Life" dark enough already. The book begins 1975 drug bust Arkansas judge persuaded free Mr. Richards confiscating hunting knife (which still hangs courtroom) picture taken him. How Mr. Richards get lucky? "I really can't explain it," says, deadpan, now. "Maybe I've got honest face." It covers many arrests too, well Mr. Richards's grueling efforts kick heroin addiction, claims done successfully 30 years ago. "Stories like aren't told much," insists. "There aren't many people willing tell them." Then health hazards book describes. Like electrocution. "My spectacular one Sacramento. ..." says smile, drifting fond-sounding reverie involves guitar string touching ungrounded microphone clouds smoke billowing mouth. He good laugh memory finding hospital hearing doctor say, "Well, either wake don't." "Life" already attracted undue attention schoolyard-sounding anatomical swipe Mr. Jagger. But book pulls punches, disses serious that. "Cold-blooded" "vicious" two printable words uses describe Brian Jones. Allen Ginsberg "old gasbag." Mick Taylor, former Rolling Stone, "didn't anything" left band, Donald Cammell, film director ("Performance," starring Mr. Jagger Anita Pallenberg, Mr. Richards's longtime lover partner crime), couldn't commit suicide quickly enough suit Mr. Richards. (He shot 1996.) When Marlon Brando propositioned Ms. Pallenberg, Mr. Richards remembers replying this: "Later, pal." As Mr. Jagger, complaints deep-seated. They involve credit hogging, social climbing, egomania, insecurity, unethical business behavior — comes Freudian's holiday anyone who's ever watched bare-chested young Jagger Richards vamp together — uncertain sexual identity. There's also cool condescension Mr. Jagger's contributions duo's songwriting. And nasty nickname two, like "Disco Boy." In conversation this, Mr. Richards emphatically blase: "It's bound somewhat rough, point I'm trying tell story Day 1 now," says. And sure: "There's odd conflict there. But weigh out, things count nothing." Mr. Richards see Mr. Jagger knew book ahead time. "The important thing me," says, "was Mick seen knew what."And anything one Stone say another Stone really give offense point? "No." But anything new said Stones anyway? As "Life" emphatically demonstrates, answer yes. And surprisingly revelatory material appears Mr. Richards jokingly calls "Keefs Guitar Workshop." Here secrets world's famous rock riffs almost toy-level equipment recorded, like cassette recorder onto Mr. Richards dubbed guitar layer guitar layer "Street Fighting Man," "Jumpin' Jack Flash" part "Gimme Shelter." Here's silent beats Elvis Presley's "Heartbreak Hotel" worked way Mr. Richards's inspired solos. Mr. Fox found "Heartbreak Hotel" key Mr. Richards's best musical memories. Some well known music critics. But Mr. Richards makes fascinating layman's level. And surprised find early readers haven't skipping musicology, even though book cordially invites so. What finds gratifying written "Life" chance readers grasp breadth range book's material. He rare memoirist say, without hyperbole, "that I hoped worth sharing people turned far important I could possibly imagine." It's getting late. Time leave bright orange room Mr. Richards's name emblazoned director's chair; assorted music awards platinum records everywhere; there's discreet little skull middle wall mirror; Louis Vuitton guitar case — ad Vuitton — parked corner. But items likeliest catch eye ones coffee table: loose cigarettes neatly arrayed holder, lighter, cigarettes pack. "Do mind I smoke?" asked first appeared. Easy one: Who, aside Keith Richards certain legal authorities, ever kept Keith Richards anything? But hour gone by, hasn't touched cigarettes. He hasn't even looked them. He done one thing make resemble sullen, haunted, diabolically beautiful creature cover book, one hellfire blazing hand meet blurry white thing he's smoking. "That?" says innocently asked picture. "Oh, that's lighting cigarette. That's I doing."
aned Woodward's Fire Leslie H. Gelb September 23, 2010 I 1:32pm The president team cooperated famed author's new book. Leslie H. Gelb fallout—and Obama's Wars shows U.S. stuck open-ended conflict. Lots White House officials observed Bob Woodward, Mr. First Draft History, repeatedly boldly slipping behind closed doors President Obama's intimate advisers. They knew happening. The president's men helping The Washington Post's sleuth write "the inside story" boss masterfully managed trying Herculean labors—the war Afghanistan. There's one big problem dealing Woodward manner: Once boss opens doors spilling secrets, many subordinates feel liberated "tell side story." By time exhausted tales heroism shortcomings fellow senior officials, well, one looks terribly heroic. Let's start Obama, emerges pages Obama's Wars is—brilliant, emotionless, abstract, focused, confused, Chicago law-school professor presidents' clothes. He obviously wanted Woodward portray brilliant intellectual leader government giving much help solving Afghan mystery, trudged on, best anyone possibly could terrible circumstances. The worst circumstance, Team Obama alleged Woodward, Pentagon leadership U.S. generals give real choices asking for. He wanted options troop increases below, even far below, generals giving him. He didn't get them. He wanted strategy U.S. forces would drawn reached projected peak 100,000 (more three times number George W. Bush left him). The military didn't provide that, either. As say Missouri, "Give break." If commander chief United States doesn't know get wants U.S. military, might want something that. And many generals White House picked guide might told go task. To cut chase: Obama didn't understand do—tell Defense Secretary Bob Gates tell generals either meet president's wishes fired. Republican presidents that. And so, Woodward describes, Obama write strategy himself. This still awful situation springs two sources. One president clear enough thinking objectives Afghanistan, military rest us must real clarity pursue wars. Woodward right. Here Obama quotes illustrate problem. The president told Woodward didn't think Afghan war "classic" terms U.S. winning losing. "I think terms of: Do successfully prosecute strategy results country stronger rather weaker end?" What earth mean? Or try one, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) whether July 2011 deadline begin withdrawal firm: "I say that. I can't let war without end, I can't lose whole Democratic Party." Does mean Obama really believes war, party doesn't? Or White House aides: "This needs plan we're going hand get Afghanistan." So, wanted plan, gotten plan. He president all. Which leads second problem: When president clear tough problem, military smells vacillations. And sure don't like vacillation comes dispatching men women war. Americans don't fathom well military mentality. The military countries throughout history doesn't like go war; like build arms overall strength. But war, want troops, fewer restrictions use, all, victory, victory, victory. Since Vietnam, smell vacillation among Democrats, don't like it. For part, Democrats see insubordination worse among military toward them, don't care suits either. It's happy circumstance. Woodward didn't explore underlying reality, critical Americans understand. breakAd The White House clash military could get worse latest news Gen. Stanley McChrystal's firing naughty things said White House reporter. According preliminary Army investigation, general—and perhaps even senior Army aides—were sources nasty quotes. It guys—you know, usual culprits, Navy civilians. There formal inquiries this, nothing good come them. There's another important thread running throughout Woodward account that, I believe, gets wrong right. That is, Woodward's repeated insistence open bitter policy brawls good old Situation Room (the inner sanctum White House meetings) Afghan policy. Mr. Instant Historian paints picture war all. My information always relative agreement major policy. Based sources, doubt Secretary State Hillary Clinton, Defense Secretary Bob Gates, Joint Chiefs Chairman Mike Mullen almost always quite cordial full lock step. They, along NSC Adviser Jim Jones field commanders like General McChrystal General Petraeus, key players. Of course, Vice President Joe Biden Chief Staff Rahm Emanuel regular critics policy heading. The generals lobby positions public—in advance presidential decisions. And that's big no-no. But standard, almost Obama's top advisers much. The day West Point speech last December, set firm date July 2011 begin unspecified U.S. troop withdrawals, almost advisers publicly stated maybe one didn't take date seriously, everything "conditions based." That group rebels included Gates Clinton. So, anything, Obama's top counselors less united—sometimes seemed going. Here Petraeus say Woodward subject goals, it's stunner: "You recognize also I don't think win war. I think keep fighting. It's little bit like Iraq, actually.... Yes, enormous progress Iraq. But still horrific attacks Iraq, stay vigilant. You stay it. This kind fight we're rest lives probably kids' lives." The brilliant general said much others last year. It's enough knock socks off. So far, heroes narrative, self-described heroic skeptics war warriors would fight forever. Doubtless, President Obama want fight open-ended war. He's sworn time again, I believe him, despite history calling "victory" "defeat" Taliban al Qaeda. But Woodward book demonstrates Obama team don't know get there. Sid US Hikers Were Seized Iraq By Babak Sarfaraz Posted June 24, 2010, Printed October 22, 2010 http://www.theinvestigativefund.org/investigations/internationa1/1338/ KURDISTAN PROVINCE, IRAN— Since arrest last July Iranian forces near Iraq border, three Americans — Shane Bauer, Josh Fattal Sarah Shourd — center high-stakes diplomatic struggle Tehran Washington. Iranian authorities repeatedly accused three entering Iran conduct espionage. Meanwhile, friends family three, along State Department, Committee Protect Journalists, The Nation The Investigative Fund [Bauer written Investigative Fund stories appeared The Nation Mother Jones], rejected spying charge suggested Americans accidentally crossed border recreational hike. Despite well- publicized visit detainees' mothers May, Iran released little information circumstances arrest status case. The Nation The Investigative Fund located two witnesses arrest claim Bauer, Fattal Shourd Iraqi territory arrested — Iran, Iranian officials asserted. Two additional sources report Revolutionary Guards officer likely ordered detention since arrested charges smuggling, kidnapping murder. The witnesses residents Kurdish village Iraq called Zalem, lies miles Iran border; declined identified, fearing retaliation Iranian forces, known conduct missions across border. The witnesses separately reported noticing three Americans hiked mountain scenic Khormal region, straddles border. Part mountain lies Iraq part Iran, except watchtowers occasional signposts, border largely unmarked, although local residents familiar boundaries. The witnesses, followed Western-looking hikers curiosity, say around 2 pm July 31, hikers descended mountain, uniformed guards NAJA, Iran's national police force, waved hikers toward Iranian side using "threatening" "menacing" gestures. When calls ignored, one officer fired round air. As hikers continued hesitate, guards walked yards Iraqi territory, lack jurisdiction, apprehended them. These witness accounts corroborate statement Bauer made May 20 tele-vised reunion Tehran hotel hikers mothers. As New York Times reported, Bauer "denied walked Iran, accused doing, stopping saying, 'We can't really talk that." Farhad Lohoni, local tribal leader, previously claimed American hikers snatched Iraq cross-border raid Iranian agents, reported Daily Telegraph August 2009. Lohoni said relatives seen group men cross border Iraq, told Telegraph hikers "were targeted captured group came Iran, ignoring Iraq's sovereignty. We know means Iran must wanted take Americans hostage sensitive time." A State Department spokesman said unaware evidence three arrested Iraqi territory would comment further. Once captured, Bauer, Fattal Shourd sped car local headquarters Iranian Revolutionary Guards Marivan, town close border province Kurdistan. When arrived, according two sources, Americans remanded custody Lt. Col. Heyva Taab, head Revolutionary Guards' intelligence unit region. According sources — former member Revolutionary Guards official serves provincial government Sanandaj — Taab would authority order Americans' detention eventual transfer Tehran. A branch Iranian military least 125,000 personnel, Revolutionary Guards responsible maintaining national security throughout Islamic Republic. "When I heard news arrested American hikers, I immediately thought, This work intelligence arm Revolutionary Guards, people region," says Idris Ahmedi, Iranian Kurdish exile regional expert visiting scholar Georgetown University. "I thought likely lured Iranian Kurdistan, could arrest them. It consistent Iran's past actions." Less month later, late August 2009, Taab arrested charged July 6 murder son Mostafa Shirzadi, Imam Joma (Friday prayer leader) Marivan, influential cleric region. Shirzadi's nephew also allegedly killed Taab. Since arrest Taab implicated vast criminal enterprise encompassing profitable smuggling operation dozens murders, rapes kidnappings. According Sanandaj official, numerous lawsuits, perhaps hundreds, filed Taab Kurdistan, alleging libel, theft, rape, kidnapping murder. Taab's case twice judge, awaits execution Tehran prison. Although state-run Iranian press reported Taab's crimes, made public series articles January February Kurdish news site, Kurdistan Va Kurdnews, run Kurdistan Democratic Party. A February 17 article describes Taab head "criminal band" reports Taab seven accomplices arrest Revolutionary Guards role vast number illegal killings. Several sources describe Taab central power Kurdistan province. According locals experts, control border lies hands Revolutionary Guards, particular intelligence unit, Etelaat Sepah, whose local division commanded Taab five years. "At point it's really Sepah, Revolutionary Guards, charge, especially western provinces, especially Americans side, Iraq," says Kaveh Ehsani, assistant professor international studies DePaul University Iran expert serves contributing editor journal Middle East Report. "On surface security force [NAJA] charge, really Revolutionary Guards control borders." It region where, according several Iran experts, smuggling cross-border traffic routine. The Iraq-Iran border "relatively porous it's mountainous," says Faraz Sanei, Iran researcher Human Rights Watch, issued report last year political freedom Iranian Kurdistan. Sanei describes border common escape route dissidents —journalists, human rights advocates Iranian Kurds—as well commonly used trade route goods. "Smuggling something taken place continues take place there, whether goods humans across border. It's something happens quite often." Soon Taab took charge Sepah northwestern quadrant Kurdistan, began enrich black-market border economy. According Sanandaj official former Revolutionary Guards officer, firsthand knowledge Taab's activities, Taab's first scheme involved selling merchandise confiscated petty smugglers, known koolbars, traffic consumer goods across border (a trade depicted Iranian film A Time Drunken Horses, won Camera d'Or Cannes 2000). The region also home variety Kurdish nationalist groups demanding autonomy central Tehran government. One these, Party Free Life Kurdistan (PJAK), affiliated Kurdistan Workers' Party, Kurdish separatist organization engages armed conflict within Turkey labeled terrorist organization United States governments. Since 2005 PJAK, based mountains Kurdish Iraq, open conflict Tehran claimed responsibility killing dozens Revolutionary Guards soldiers cross-border raids Iranian military bases, well February 2007 downing Iranian military helicopter shoulder-launched missile Khoy, Western Azerbaijan province, killed thirteen Iranian soldiers. It speculated Kurdish militants enjoy US support. In April 2006, Representative Dennis Kucinich wrote letter President Bush questioning whether US government "fomenting opposition supporting military operations Iran among insurgent groups Iranian ethnic minority groups, operating Iraq." Kucinich named two groups, including PJAK. In November year, Seymour Hersh reported The New Yorker "Israel United States also working together support Kurdish resistance group known Party Free Life Kurdistan," government consultant told Israeli government provided "equipment training" PJAK. The United States Israel denied involvement PJAK. Still, allegations support gained substantial traction inside Iran may undergirded Taab's decision detain Bauer, Fattal Shourd well repeated public charges espionage three. In early April, instance, Iranian Intelligence Minister Heydar Moslehi told Iran's Press TV "it quite obvious us three Americans arrested Iran last year links Western Israeli intelligence services." The Iranian government retaliated rising Kurdish militancy launching counteroffensive PJAK, inside Iran across border Iraq. In August 2007, example, Iranian soldiers crossed Iraq attacked several villages, McClatchy reported. Most recently, June 4, officials Iraq's semiautonomous Kurdish region alleged "a small unit Iranian soldiers," including tank several vehicles, penetrated mile Iraqi Kurdistan's Arbil province search Kurdish rebels. Until arrest, Taab key player Iran's counter- offensive. The former Revolutionary Guards officer says several current members Guards told Taab's stated goal "completely wipe PJAK" jurisdiction. According Alunedi, scholar Georgetown, Taab involved recent cross-border assassinations Iranian Kurds Iraqi Kurdistan. The Kurdish weekly Awena reported Taab unit assassinated two Kurds December 15, 2008. According former officer Sanandaj official, Taab's criminal enterprise grew beyond smuggling 2007, made first forays murder. Koolbars, petty border smugglers, often killed land mines fatally shot border police. So Taab concocted scheme kidnap koolbars well ordinary unemployed Iranian Kurdish civilians, dress uniforms PJAK insurgents kill them—claiming they'd died military clash—in order collect bounty, high $40,000 head, superiors Revolutionary Guards. He assisted plot least nine others, seven apprehended. The article Kurdistan Va Kurdnews named seven, including Haji Majid Muqimiyan Kermansha, identified ringleader. PJAK officially denied involvement border clashes, including May 3, 2009, post Iranian website Tabnak, published Mohsen Rezai, former head Revolutionary Guards. Many PJAK clashes may, fact, "bogus," said Sanandaj official. "More less clashes PJAK reported area since Heyva Taab gang busted." A mother one koolbar tearfully described son's disappearance. She said went missing day early 2009 government later claimed clash PJAK taken place. The woman, resident border town Iranian Kurdistan, plaintiff one lawsuits Taab; asked name location mentioned, fear would harm case court. Taab's scheme wildly successful, according Sanandaj official, said one bank account Taab's name nearly $6 million deposited since 2008. This macabre scheme ended spring 2009, Taab killed local official's brother seeking work area and, decisively, last July killed cleric's son. On June 11 Mohammad Javad Larijani, secretary general Iran's High Council Human Rights, said government's investigation nearly complete trial Bauer, Fattal Shourd "should far now." In statement issued June 17, mothers hikers called Iran either prosecute release children. "Iran legitimate reason stage release move forward fair trial children openly answer allegations them." "These new revelations, indeed true, show hikers victims political machinations manipulation," said Hadi Ghaemi, executive director International Campaign Human Rights Iran. "The fact held long without prosecution strongly supports trend. Under Iranian laws, committed crime released immediately. Their Iranian lawyer, studied judicial files them, consistently maintained charge illegal entry, subject fine arbitrary detention long. With new information, even charge appears fabricated, basis holding them." As press date, Shane Bauer, Josh Fattal Sarah Shourd detained Iran ten months twenty-three days. Senate Republicans Filibuster Fair Pay For Women Matt Finkelstein The first bill President Obama signed taking office Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act, made easier women seek justice pay discrimination. At time, Sens. Susan Collins (R-ME), Kay Bailey Hutchison (R-TX) Olympia Snowe (R-ME) joined Democrats overcome strong Republican opposition bill. But today, three Republican senators voted motion proceed Paycheck Fairness Act, bill "would strengthen current laws gender-based wage discrimination." The motion defeated vote 58-41, falling two votes short 60 needed bill considered Senate floor. This first time Paycheck Fairness Act stalled Senate. In 2008, upper chamber failed vote bill approved House, passed legislation 2009 support 10 Republicans. Women earn barely three-quarters male counterparts make work, conservatives invented number ludicrous reasons opposing equal pay legislation. For example, Heritage Foundation suggested equal pay laws actually hurt women businesses simply won't hire required pay fair wages. And Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) claimed women would receive better compensation "education training."
